ACCTG201.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
ACCTG201.description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts of financial accounting, including the collection, recording, summarization, and interpretation of accounting data.

ACCTG202.title: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
ACCTG202.description: This course emphasizes the use of accounting information for internal purposes (managerial accounting).

ACCTG211.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
ACCTG211.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
ACCTG211.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 021or 1.5 units of high school algebra C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG305.title: Financial Statements and Management Decisions
ACCTG305.description: Impact of management's financing, investing, and operating decisions on GAAPâ€“based financial statements.
ACCTG305.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211andFIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG310.title: Federal Taxation I
ACCTG310.description: Study of income determination concepts for individuals and corporations, impact of taxation on decisions, elementary research techniques, and ethical standards.
ACCTG310.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orFIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG340.title: Cost Accounting
ACCTG340.description: Accounting for manufacturing concerns, actual and standard cost systems, and managerial uses of cost data.
ACCTG340.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orACCTG 311 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG403.title: Auditing
ACCTG403.description: Financial compliance, internal, and operational audits; standards and procedures; sampling; EDP auditing; professional issues; application of concepts through written responses.
ACCTG403.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 371orACCTG 471 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG404.title: Managerial Accounting: Economic Perspective
ACCTG404.description: Accounting techniques as planning, control, and motivating devices in business and other organizations; accounting data for decision-making and performance evaluation.
ACCTG404.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211,STAT 200orECON 102 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG405.title: Principles of Taxation I
ACCTG405.description: Elements of tax policy and tax-planning concepts for personal and business decision-making; with emphasis on taxation of individuals.
ACCTG405.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211;BA 301orFIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG410.title: Federal Taxation II
ACCTG410.description: An examination of the rules and forms used to compute the federal tax liability of corporations and partners.
ACCTG410.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 310 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG423.title: Accounting Data Analytics
ACCTG423.description: Get hands-on experience using foundational data analytics tools and techniques to analyze and interpret accounting data across financial, managerial, audit, and tax domains.

ACCTG426.title: Financial Statement Analysis
ACCTG426.description: The exploration of conventional and advanced methods of analyzing financial statements, including the assessment of earnings quality.
ACCTG426.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG462.title: Governmental and Not-for-Profit Accounting
ACCTG462.description: Provides an understanding of governmental and not-for-profit accounting theory, procedures, and financial statements.
ACCTG462.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 311orACCTG 471 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG471.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
ACCTG471.description: Theory and practice issues in income concepts and value measurement; GAAP; revenues, costs, assets, liabilities, and equities.
ACCTG471.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orACCTG 311 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG472.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
ACCTG472.description: Off-balance sheet financing; special issues in cost capitalization, liabilities, and equities; matching; funds flow statements; statement analysis; inflation accounting.
ACCTG472.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 371orACCTG 471 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG473.title: Advanced Financial Accounting
ACCTG473.description: Reporting for multi-corporate enterprises, business combinations, quasi-reorganizations, and selected contemporary reporting problems.
ACCTG473.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 472 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ACCTG483.title: Forensic Accounting
ACCTG483.description: Learn about the principles and practices of forensic accounting, with a focus on investigative techniques, fraud detection, litigation support, and the analysis of financial data for legal and dispute resolution purposes.

AFAM100.title: Living While Black: Themes in African American Thought and Experience
AFAM100.description: Explore what it means to be Black in America by engaging with questions about identity and authenticity, freedom and unfreedom, radicalism and reform, gender and sexuality, and the role of music in African American life.
AFAM100.prerequisites_raw: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

AFAM100N.title: Black Freedom Struggles
AFAM100N.description: Explore what it means to be Black in America by engaging with questions about identity and authenticity, freedom and unfreedom, radicalism and reform, gender and sexuality, and the role of music in African American life.

AFAM409.title: Racial and Ethnic Inequality in America
AFAM409.description: The impact of inequality and discrimination on individual and group identity among various racial and ethnic groups.

AFR110N.title: Introduction to Contemporary Africa
AFR110N.description: Consideration of influences and forces shaping modern African society; analysis of current local and global problems and issues facing Africa are the central focus of the course.

AGBM101.title: Economic Principles of Agribusiness Decision Making
AGBM101.description: This course introduces students to microeconomic principles in the context of food and agriculture.
AGBM101.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM102.title: Economics of the Food System
AGBM102.description: Introduction to topics designed to develop an understanding of how the food production, processing, and marketing system works and evolves.
AGBM102.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM106.title: Agribusiness Problem-Solving
AGBM106.description: Development of quantitative problem-solving skills applied to specific examples of agribusiness management problems, using Excel spreadsheets.
AGBM106.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite AGBM 101;ECON 102;STAT 200;STAT 240;STAT 250;SCM 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM302.title: Food Product Marketing
AGBM302.description: Analysis of economic and psychological determinants of the demand for food; marketing decisions in an increasingly consumer-driven food system.
AGBM302.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (AGBM 101orECON 102) andAGBM 102andAGBM 106 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM308W.title: Strategic Decision-Making in Agribusiness
AGBM308W.description: Utilize case studies to investigate strategic decision-making among agribusiness firms, highlighting how information and market power shape strategies.
AGBM308W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite AGBM 101;ECON 102,AGBM 102,AGBM 106 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM320.title: Markets and Prices: Analysis and Forecasting
AGBM320.description: Understand how prices are determined; develop the skill to analyze and forecast how prices change as the underlying conditions change.
AGBM320.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite AGBM 101;ECON 102,AGBM 102,AGBM 106,SCM 200;STAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

AGBM408.title: Financial Decision-Making for Agribusiness
AGBM408.description: Develop financial management and business analysis skills, integrating previous course work and finance training; principles of financial management, planning, control.

AGBM440.title: Food Product Innovation Management
AGBM440.description: A problem-based course designed to enhance decision-making skills in the context of industry's approach to developing new food products.
AGBM440.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite AGBM 302or junior/senior standing in Food Science

AGBM460.title: Managing the Food System
AGBM460.description: Firm management in the food system; coordination with suppliers and customers, including supply chain management, strategic thinking, risk management.

AMST140Y.title: Religion in American Life and Thought
AMST140Y.description: The course aims to cast light on contemporary religious life in the United States by looking at the history of American religion.

ANTH1.title: Understanding Humans
ANTH1.description: This course tells the story of humankind, how we as a species developed, and how modern Homo sapiens have developed more cultural complexity over time, moving, in the last 12,000 years, from a worldwide small population of hunter-foragers to a population so large that it strains the planet's resources, with nation-states competing for the loyalty of their citizens with powerful ethnic and religious enclaves and also with global corporations.

ANTH21.title: Introductory Biological Anthropology
ANTH21.description: The role of human biology and evolution in culture, society, and behavior.
ANTH21.prerequisites_raw: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

ANTH22.title: Humans as Primates
ANTH22.description: The biological basis of human behavior within the context of primate biology, behavior, and evolution.
ANTH22.prerequisites_raw: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

ANTH45N.title: Cultural Diversity: A Global Perspective
ANTH45N.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the concepts and evidence used in understanding the cultural diversity of our planet.

ART10.title: Introduction to Visual Studies
ART10.description: Introduction to visual studies; pictorial space and the principles of visual organization.

ART20.title: Introduction to Drawing
ART20.description: Introductory experience in making of art through drawing media; designed for nonmajors seeking general overview of studio practice.

ART211Y.title: Introduction to Digital Art and Design Criticism
ART211Y.description: An introduction to the language, aesthetics, and cultural impacts of digital art and design in contemporary society.
ART211Y.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ASIA100.title: What is Asia?
ASIA100.description: What are the factors that bind and define a region? What makes a geographical area, a set of cultures, or a certain group of people into a single entity? Who decides? Asian history provides a view of how a region is formed and reshaped over time.

BA100.title: Introduction to Business
BA100.description: A comprehensive view of the contemporary environment of business. This course provides a broad overview of the study of business and its environment, organization, operation, and interrelationships with government and society.

BA243.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
BA243.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
BA243.prerequisites_raw: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

BA304.title: Management and Organization
BA304.description: An overview of a body of knowledge that exists concerning the management of modern organizations.

BA321.title: Contemporary Skills for Business Professionals
BA321.description: Technological and interpersonal skills for the contemporary business professional, stressing collaborative learning, electronic inquiry and communications, critical thinking, and problem-solving.
BA321.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211andECON 102orECON 104andENGL 15 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA322.title: Negotiation Skills for Business Professionals
BA322.description: Effectiveness of the business professional in team settings, especially the capacity to execute both technologically and cooperatively through group exercises.
BA322.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211andECON 102orECON 104andENGL 15 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA364Y.title: International Business and Society
BA364Y.description: Business organizations and the sociocultural environment; current issues; corporate responsibility; international and multinational business environments.
BA364Y.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 202D,MGMT 301 US;IL This course can be used to satisfy the International Cultures (IL) or the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

BA420.title: Preparation for Career Management
BA420.description: This course emphasizes effective career planning by closely examining oneself, the business world, and communication styles and strategies.
BA420.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 321orBA 322 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA421.title: Project Management
BA421.description: Introduction to Project Management, covering all phases of a project in proposal development, planning, execution, and closing.
BA421.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 321orBA 322 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA422W.title: Strategic Business Planning
BA422W.description: Study of strategic planning and implementation in multi-industry, multicultural, and multi-national settings with emphasis on sustaining competitive advantages.
BA422W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 321andBA 322andBA 421andFIN 301andMGMT 301andMKTG 301andSCM 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA462.title: Business Strategy
BA462.description: Interpretation of business concepts in the analysis of problems related to the successful management of a company, institution, or organization.
BA462.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite FIN 301,MGMT 301,MKTG 301W,BA 364Y, and 7th-semester standing or higher. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

BA495A.title: Internship in Business
BA495A.description: Guided professional practicum in business consisting of 3 or 6 credits of supervised fieldwork in business.
BA495A.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 321;BA 322;BA 420and completion of 6 credits at the 300- or 400- level in student's option Note This internship is an opportunity to apply the theories and concepts taught throughout the program. With approval from the academic program coordinator, you can engage in an assignment at your workplace that goes beyond your regular job duties, or you could work on a special initiative with a local organization in your community. Whichever path you choose, this internship is an opportunity to apply classroom knowledge in a real-world business setting and demonstrate your willingness to go beyond your regular job responsibilities.

BBH101.title: Introduction to Biobehavioral Health
BBH101.description: Introduction to an interdisciplinary study of health, examining the interaction of biological processes and behavior on health.
BBH101.prerequisites_raw: GHW This course may be used to satisfy the Health and Wellness (GHW) requirement.

BBH301W.title: Values and Ethics in Biobehavioral Health Research and Practice
BBH301W.description: Examines bases for choices among values in personal and professional relations in human development processes and supporting services.

BBH302.title: Diversity and Health
BBH302.description: Examines the relationship diverse personal and sociocultural factors (e.g., socioeconomic class, race-ethnicity, gender, age, and sexual orientation) have with health.

BBH305.title: Introduction to Global Health Issues
BBH305.description: Course will develop awareness of contemporary issues in global health.

BBH310.title: Research Strategies for Studying Biobehavioral Health
BBH310.description: Surveys the various research methodologies used in biomedical research, including case, epidemiological, quasiexperimental and experimental approaches.

BBH311.title: Interdisciplinary Integration in Biobehavioral Health
BBH311.description: A review of literature relevant to the concepts and findings of different scientific domains as they apply to biobehavioral health.

BBH315.title: Gender and Biobehavioral Health
BBH315.description: Interdisciplinary study of gender, examining the interaction of biological, behavioral, and sociocultural factors on health differentials throughout the lifespan.

BBH316.title: Foundations and Principles of Health Promotion
BBH316.description: Basic exposure and skills development in theory and practice in health promotion.

BBH411W.title: Research and Applications in Biobehavioral Health
BBH411W.description: Research methods, multi-level analyses, and applications in biobehavioral health.

BBH416.title: Health Promotion II: Planning, Implementation, and Evaluation
BBH416.description: Planning, implementation, and evaluation of health promotion, prevention, and intervention programs; emphasizing evaluation.

BBH432.title: Biobehavioral Aspects of Stress
BBH432.description: This course will cover the way stress response occurs in humans and how those responses can affect other aspects of physical, psychological, behavioral, and cognitive functioning.

BBH440(U.S.;IL).title: Principles of Epidemiology
BBH440(U.S.;IL).description: Theory of epidemiology and significant case studies; potential applications to health care.

BBH451.title: Pharmacological Influences on Health
BBH451.description: Biological and behavioral aspects of therapeutic and recreational drug use and misuse, and their relationships to health.

BIOL110.title: Biology: Basic Concepts and Biodiversity
BIOL110.description: A study of the fundamental concepts of biology, including the evolution of the major groups of organisms. This is the first biology course taken by students who intend to major in biology. It provides a foundation in the basic concepts that govern life, including the evolutionary processes that have led to the biodiversity seen today.
BIOL110.prerequisites_raw: GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

BIOL127.title: Introduction to Plant Biology
BIOL127.description: Cellular structure, organization, and metabolism; plant anatomy and physiological processes; plant reproduction and development; genetics and evolution; relationships and features of plant groups. Students who have passed BIOL 240W may not schedule this course.

BIOL129.title: Mammalian Anatomy
BIOL129.description: Anatomy of a mammal, with special reference to that of man.
BIOL129.prerequisites_raw: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

BIOL133.title: Genetics and Evolution of the Human Species
BIOL133.description: Human heredity and evolution, individual and social implications.

BIOL141.title: Introductory Physiology
BIOL141.description: Normal structure and function of the animal body, with special emphasis on human body systems.

BIOL155.title: Introduction to the Biology of Aging
BIOL155.description: Examination of human aging from a biological perspective. Population demographics, physiological and pathological changes, and healthy lifestyles are discussed. Students who have passed BIOL 409 may not schedule this course.
BIOL155.prerequisites_raw: GN This course course may be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

BIOL161.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology I - Lecture
BIOL161.description: Human Anatomy and Physiology I - Lecture

BIOL163.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
BIOL163.description: Students will build a strong foundation in the form and function of the human body from the cellular to the gross anatomical level.

BIOL177.title: Biology of Sex
BIOL177.description: Basic structure and function of the human reproductive system. Physiology of gametogenesis, fertilization, contraception, gestation, parturition, lactation, and sexual behavior.

BLAW243.title: Legal Environment of Business
BLAW243.description: Social control through law: courts, basic policies underlying individual and contractual rights in everyday society. May not be used to satisfy Smeal College baccalaureate degree requirements.

CAS100.title: Effective Speech
CAS100.description: Introduction to speech communication: formal speaking, group discussion, analysis and evaluation of messages.

CAS203.title: Interpersonal Communication
CAS203.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

CAS204.title: Communication Research Methods
CAS204.description: Overview of the skills necessary to evaluate commonly reported communication research.

CAS212.title: Professional Public Speaking
CAS212.description: Organizing, adapting and presenting ideas in public informative, persuasive, technical and ceremonial speeches.

CAS215.title: Argumentation
CAS215.description: This course provides an in-depth examination of argumentation in both public and private contexts.

CAS252.title: Business and Professional Communication
CAS252.description: Review and practice of various communication forms used in modern organizations.

CAS271N.title: Intercultural Communication
CAS271N.description: Focus on topics such as language, identity, prejudice, and intergroup relations on a domestic/ international level.

CAS283.title: Communication and Information Technology
CAS283.description: Introduction to communication technology and information management; intended for students in the liberal arts.

CAS301.title: Rhetorical Theory
CAS301.description: History and theory of public advocacy and civic discourse.

CAS302.title: Social Influence
CAS302.description: Explores how humans influence others through communication.

CAS303.title: Introduction to Communication Theory
CAS303.description: This course is intended as a foundational course in communication theory for Communication Arts and Sciences majors and others interested in social science theory in general. It is designed to show how communication theory can be applied to understand and improve communication in your professional (and personal) life. The theories examined will span the range of communication contexts, including interpersonal, group, organizational, mediated, and cross-cultural interactions.

CAS321.title: Rhetoric and Law
CAS321.description: A survey of the literature on the role of rhetoric in law, including trial advocacy, appellate argument, and judicial reasoning.

CAS340.title: Communication and Civility
CAS340.description: Communication behaviors contributing to civil and uncivil discourse; their implications in business, public life, across cultures and in interpersonal relationships.

CAS352.title: Organizational Communication
CAS352.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.
CAS352.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CAS390.title: Qualitative Research Methods
CAS390.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

CAS403.title: Interpersonal Communication Theory and Research
CAS403.description: Course foci center on contemporary theory and research, interpersonal communication in personal and professional relationships, and a research practicum in which students conduct an original research study.
CAS403.prerequisites_raw: 3rd Semester Standing or 6 credits of CAS

CAS404.title: Conflict Resolution and Negotiation
CAS404.description: Theories and strategies important for conceptualizing, developing, and managing conflict negotiation, mediation, and third-party intervention.
CAS404.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CAS 100 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CAS426W.title: Communication Ethics
CAS426W.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

CAS452W.title: Organizational Communication Theory and Research
CAS452W.description: Explores the nature and functions of communication in organizations, with emphasis on concepts, tools, and skills for effective management of communication.

CAS455.title: Gender Roles in Communications
CAS455.description: Explores the literature on gender research in the discipline of human communication.

CAS475.title: Studies in Public Address
CAS475.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.

CAS496.title: Independent Studies
CAS496.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

CHEM110.title: Chemical Principles I
CHEM110.description: First semester of a two-semester, comprehensive general chemistry course that introduces students to the basic principles of chemistry with an emphasis on the relationships between the microscopic structure and the macroscopic properties of matter.
CHEM110.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Completion of or placement beyondMATH 22

CHEM111.title: Experimental Chemistry I
CHEM111.description: Introduction to quantitative experimentation in chemistry.

CHEM130.title: Introduction to General, Organic and Biochemistry
CHEM130.description: This course is a one-semester rigorous college-level introductory Chemistry course covering the fundamental principles of general, organic, and biochemistry. One year of high school chemistry is strongly recommended.

CHEM202.title: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry I
CHEM202.description: Introduction to organic chemistry, with emphasis on the properties of organic compounds of biochemical importance.

CMLIT10.title: World Literatures
CMLIT10.description: The development of literature around the world - from epic, legend, lyric, etc. in the oral tradition to modern written forms.

CMLIT153.title: International Cultures: Film and Literature
CMLIT153.description: Comparison of narrative techniques employed by literature and film in portraying different cultures, topics may vary each semester.

CMPEN270.title: Digital Design: Theory and Practice
CMPEN270.description: Introduction to digital systems and their design.

CMPEN351.title: Microprocessors
CMPEN351.description: Microprocessor architecture; memory system design; assembly language programming; interrupts; the stacks and subroutines; memory and I/O inter-facing; serial I/O and data communications; microprocessors applications.
CMPEN351.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPEN 271 andCMPEN 275 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPEN441.title: Operating Systems
CMPEN441.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 360 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPEN461.title: Communication Networks
CMPEN461.description: Data transmission, encoding, link control techniques, network architecture, design, protocols, and multiple access.
CMPEN461.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (CMPEN 270orCMPEN 271) and(CMPSC 121orCMPSC 201) C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPSC101.title: Introduction to Programming
CMPSC101.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
CMPSC101.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

CMPSC121.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
CMPSC121.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion

CMPSC122.title: Intermediate Programming
CMPSC122.description: Object-oriented programming, recursion, fundamental data structures (including stacks, queues, linked lists, hash tables, trees, and graphs), the basics of algorithmic analysis, and an introduction to the principles of language translation.
CMPSC122.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 121 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPSC203.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets and Databases
CMPSC203.description: Design, use, and programming of spreadsheets and data bases with applications from a range of disciplines.
CMPSC203.prerequisites_raw: Note not currently offered online through World Campus. Prerequisite 2 entrance units in mathematics

CMPSC360.title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
CMPSC360.description: Discrete mathematics and foundations for modern computer science.
CMPSC360.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 122 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPSC431W.title: Database Management Systems
CMPSC431W.description: Topics include: conceptual data modeling, relational data model, relational query languages, schema normalization, database/Internet applications, and database system issues.
CMPSC431W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 221 andENGL 202C C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPSC445.title: Applied Machine Learning in Data Science
CMPSC445.description: This course will start with an overview of supervised and unsupervised learning, and introduce the associated libraries. It covers basic machine learning concepts, tasks, and workflow using an example classification problem based on K-nearest neighbors, NaiÌˆve Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-means, and implementation using Python libraries.

CMPSC461.title: Programming Language Concepts
CMPSC461.description: Fundamental concepts of programming language design, specifications, and implementation; programming language paradigms and features; program verification.
CMPSC461.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 221orCMPSC 360 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CMPSC465.title: Data Structures and Algorithms
CMPSC465.description: Fundamental concepts of computer science: data structures, analysis of algorithms, recursion, trees, sets, graphs, sorting.
CMPSC465.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 122 and(CMPSC 360orMATH 311W) C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

COMM100N.title: The Mass Media and Society
COMM100N.description: Mass communications in the United States: organization, role, content, and effects of newspapers, magazines, television, radio, books, and films.

COMM118.title: Introduction to Media Effects
COMM118.description: Examination of individuals' selection, uses and perceptions of media and the effects of media on individuals' attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors.

COMM150.title: The Art of the Cinema
COMM150.description: The development of cinema to its present state; principles of evaluation and appreciation; examples from the past and present.

COMM160.title: Basic News Writing Skills
COMM160.description: Grammar, punctuation, spelling, and word usage skills required of journalists.

COMM180.title: Survey of Electronic Media and Telecommunications
COMM180.description: The development of electronic media and telecommunications, emphasizing social, economic, political and global impact.

COMM205.title: Gender, Diversity, and the Media
COMM205.description: Examines diversity, equity, and inclusion issues in media content, media business, and media practice.

COMM215.title: Basic Photography for Communications
COMM215.description: An introduction to digital photography, emphasizing camera skills, aesthetics, and storytelling.
COMM215.prerequisites_raw: Note Basic Photography for Communications is a hands-on, skills-oriented, results-driven class that requires students to own a suitable mobile phone along with a computer and software. Please contact Will Yurman, instructor, atwhy1@psu.eduwith any questions or concerns. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

COMM228.title: Introduction to Science Writing and Communication
COMM228.description: Learn how to write science stories that are accurate, clear, and compelling.

COMM230.title: Writing for Media
COMM230.description: The application of creativity to the practical concerns of narrative script and radio/television spot writing.
COMM230.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Enforced Prerequisite at Enrollment:ENGL 15andENGL 202 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

COMM230W.title: Writing for Media
COMM230W.description: This course is an introduction to writing for various kinds of mass communication media. Students will practice writing public relations news releases; public information announcements; print, television and radio advertisements; and news stories and editorials. Students will be given weekly writing assignments, some of which will be re-writes of earlier submissions. In-class exercises will include various writing exercises designed to get students more comfortable with writing for media.

COMM260W.title: News Writing & Reporting
COMM260W.description: News and news values; legal and ethical problems of reporting; writing and reporting news for the mass media.

COMM269.title: Photojournalism
COMM269.description: Photography for communication in print and online; creating photographs for newspapers, magazines and the web; digital camera and software skills.

COMM271.title: Principles of Multimedia Journalism
COMM271.description: The course introduces how journalists work with the tools of multimedia and how multimedia is changing journalism.

COMM280.title: Introduction to Telecommunications Technologies
COMM280.description: Students will evaluate content creation and distribution methods and demonstrate proficiency across emerging digital products and services.

COMM282.title: Introduction to Video Field Production
COMM282.description: Introduction to the pre-production, production, and post production techniques when creating video content.

COMM310.title: Digital Media Metrics
COMM310.description: Analysis of audience data for traditional and new media to create metrics for advertising, content marketing, and audience analysis.

COMM342.title: Idea Development and Media Writing
COMM342.description: Introduction to various modalities of idea development and written expression for media production.

COMM364.title: Data Visualization for Journalists
COMM364.description: Produce data-driven stories by demonstrating proficiency in sorting, filtering and using tools such as Structured Query Language, Chartbuilder, Tableau and Carto to query databases, as well as build charts and maps.

COMM380.title: Telecommunications Management
COMM380.description: Introduction to basic principles of management as they apply in electronic media industries.

COMM403.title: Law of Mass Communications
COMM403.description: Nature and theories of law; the Supreme Court and press freedom; legal problems of the mass media.

COMM405.title: Political Economy of Communications
COMM405.description: Structure and functions of American and other mass communications systems and their relationship to political and economic systems.

COMM409.title: News Media Ethics
COMM409.description: Ethical problems in the practice of journalism; principal public criticisms of news media; case study approach.

COMM410.title: International Mass Communications
COMM410.description: The role of international media in communication among and between nations and peoples.

COMM412.title: Sports, Media, and Society
COMM412.description: Sport and media relationship in American culture.

COMM419.title: World Media Systems
COMM419.description: Comparative study of modern mass systems and the evolution and structure of specific countries' systems.

COMM428A.title: Principles of Strategic Communications
COMM428A.description: Provides an overview of the various media and communications methods that comprise modern integrated marketing campaigns.

COMM428B.title: Strategic Communications Law
COMM428B.description: Analysis of laws and regulations affecting online advertising and strategic communications.
COMM428B.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite COMM 428Aand permission of the program

COMM428C.title: Strategic Communications in a Global Environment
COMM428C.description: Framework for applying public relations and advertising tools across media platforms and across cultures.
COMM428C.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite COMM 428A,COMM 428Dand permission of the program

COMM428D.title: Research & Analytics
COMM428D.description: Online research methods for strategic communication, including web analytics, online surveys, online interviews, and content analysis.
COMM428D.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite COMM 428A,STAT 200and permission of the program

COMM428E.title: Social Media Strategies
COMM428E.description: Social media â€” including social networks, visual content, podcasts, blogs and other collaborative content creation platforms â€” are changing the field of public relations. To effectively deploy social media to reach brand objectives, public relations professionals need to understand the critical roles of strategy as well as content creation. This course narrows the focus from the broad field of social media to cover the specific tools and best practices needed to conquer current and future use of social media in public relations

COMM460W.title: Reporting Techniques
COMM460W.description: Techniques in reporting news and trends at the local, regional, and county levels. Emphasis on both deadline and interpretive reporting.

COMM461.title: Magazine Writing
COMM461.description: Idea conception, writing, and editing of magazine stories.

COMM467.title: News Editing
COMM467.description: Concepts and procedures involved in processing news for various news media, but with emphasis on print media editing.

COMM469.title: Photography for the Mass Media
COMM469.description: Development of an informed and critical approach to photocommunication; individual and team projects, seminars, and critiques.

COMM492.title: Internet Law and Policy
COMM492.description: Development in the law, policy, and business of Internet-mediated communications and commerce; emphasis on impact on existing legal, regulatory, and economic models.

CRIM113.title: Introduction to Law
CRIM113.description: Introduction to law in society with a focus on criminal law, judicial code, laws of sentencing and corrections, ciminal procedure.

CRIM201.title: Presumed Innocent? Social Science of Wrongful Conviction
CRIM201.description: The criminal justice system is a human creation and some errors are expected. Sometimes guilty parties go free and sometimes innocent people are convicted. In this course, we will employ the perspective of the social scientist to understand why and how wrongful convictions occur.

CRIM406.title: Sociology of Deviance
CRIM406.description: Theory and research concerning behaviors and lifestyles viewed as significant departures from a group's normative expectations.

CRIM467.title: Law and Society
CRIM467.description: The social origins of law and legal systems; occupational careers; and decision-making of legal officials.

CRIMJ100.title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
CRIMJ100.description: Overview of the criminal justice system, including legal foundations, processing and correction of offenders, extent and types of crime, victims.
CRIMJ100.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ12.title: Criminology
CRIMJ12.description: Explanations and measurement of crime; criminal law; characteristics of criminals and victims; violent, property, white-collar, organized, and sexual crimes.
CRIMJ12.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ210.title: Policing in America
CRIMJ210.description: Police organization and operations in America.
CRIMJ210.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100or concurrentCRIMJ 100 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ220.title: Courts and the Prosecution Process
CRIMJ220.description: Purpose and function of criminal courts in society, organization, jurisdiction and staffing; prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing of offenders.
CRIMJ220.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ230.title: Corrections in America
CRIMJ230.description: Punishment and treatment of sentenced offenders, correctional institution organization, staffing, inmates, and subcultures.
CRIMJ230.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ250W.title: Research Methods in Criminal Justice
CRIMJ250W.description: Fundamental concepts of social science research, including design, measurement, sampling, and interpretation of the study of crime, law, and justice.
CRIMJ250W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CRIMJ 012 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ260.title: Statistical Analysis for the Social Sciences
CRIMJ260.description: Methods of collection, presentation, and analysis of quantitative data in the social science, procedures, interpretation, and application.
CRIMJ260.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite 2 units of high school algebra andCRIMJ 100or permission of the program

CRIMJ304.title: Security Administration
CRIMJ304.description: Interdisciplinary analysis of security and loss prevention; its administration, role in crime control and prevention, and relationship to criminal justice.

CRIMJ407.title: Victimology
CRIMJ407.description: This course will explore the legal, emotional, and social responses to the process of victimization by offenders and third parties.

CRIMJ408.title: Police Administration
CRIMJ408.description: Principles of administration as they relate to a police organization and policy development.

CRIMJ420.title: Criminal Law and Procedure
CRIMJ420.description: Common law and statutory crimes; constitutional rights of accused persons, liability of criminal justice professionals.

CRIMJ430.title: Alternatives to Incarceration
CRIMJ430.description: Control and treatment of offenders in the community, probation and parole organizations, diversion programs, innovative sentences, supervision techniques.
CRIMJ430.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100, andCRIMJ 113andCRIMJ 230, or permission of program

CRIMJ435.title: Border Security
CRIMJ435.description: This course provides knowledge about government organizations charged with American border security, guiding laws, and policies.

CRIMJ441.title: The Juvenile Justice System
CRIMJ441.description: Historical and contemporary view of juvenile justice system. Focus on analyzing components of the system, their interactions, processing, and handling of youths.

CRIMJ450W.title: Senior Seminar
CRIMJ450W.description: Capstone course exploring past, current, and future developments in criminal justice.
CRIMJ450W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Sixth-semester standing andCRIM 100orCRIMJ 100 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CRIMJ451.title: Race, Crime, and Justice
CRIMJ451.description: This course focuses on the significance of race, class, and ethnicity to criminal justice processing and criminal offending.

CRIMJ465.title: Ethics in Criminal Justice
CRIMJ465.description: Ethical behavior in the criminal justice system.
CRIMJ465.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100or permission of program C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CSD100.title: Preventing Vocal Abuse, Misuse, and Disorders
CSD100.description: Principles of the voice mechanisms, preventing vocal abuse, and promoting vocal health across the lifespan.
CSD100.prerequisites_raw: GHW The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Health and Wellness (GHW) requirement. US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

CSD269.title: Deaf Culture
CSD269.description: Explores the economic, social, psychological, and political aspects of the deaf culture and its interaction with the majority hearing culture.
CSD269.prerequisites_raw: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

CYBER100.title: Computer Systems Literacy
CYBER100.description: This is an introductory university-level course in computer systems literacy. The history, architecture and operation of computing systems and underlying computing theory are covered.

CYBER221.title: Overview of Information Security
CYBER221.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
CYBER221.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SRA 111and (CMPSC 101orIST 140orCMPSC 121) C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER262.title: Cyber-Defense Studio
CYBER262.description: This studio course teaches four basic hands-on cyber-defense skills: configuring a firewall, implementing a host-based intrusion detection software tool, using the Metasploit tool to do penetration testing, and implementing a network intrusion detection tool.
CYBER262.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (CYBER 100 or CYBER 100S)andIST 140 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER342W.title: Cyber Incident Handling and Response
CYBER342W.description: This course provides the student with the background, experience and perspective that is required to document organizational preparation for cyber incidents, document cyber incident impact and resolution, document response strategies, as well as integrate business continuity planning into the organization.
CYBER342W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CYBER 262,SRA 221andSRA 231 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER362.title: Cybersecurity Analytics Studio
CYBER362.description: This studio course teaches fundamental data-driven cybersecurity analytics skills using programming skills acquired in earlier courses.
CYBER362.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite STAT 200andIST 261andCYBER 262 Concurrent SRA 365 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER366.title: Malware Analytics
CYBER366.description: Malware Analytics is an intermediate course required for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity Analytics and Operations. It is a three-credit hands-on course that teaches principles and practice of malware detection, analysis, and defense.
CYBER366.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite IST 242andIST 261andCYBER 262 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER440.title: Cybersecurity Capstone
CYBER440.description: Cybersecurity Capstone is an advanced, culminating course for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity. This course provides the student with a practical exercise, designed by the instructor.

CYBER451.title: Network Security
CYBER451.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
CYBER451.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER454.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
CYBER454.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
CYBER454.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

CYBER456.title: Information Security Management
CYBER456.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
CYBER456.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

DA101.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
DA101.description: Introduces students to foundational concepts that are used in the data analytics industry to understand and frame projects

DA201W.title: Descriptive Analytics
DA201W.description: Introduces students to the core areas of descriptive analytics, where the main objective is to answer "what happened" in a project. Students will learn how to accurately describe the attributes of data variables available to them for their projects. Students will have the opportunity to work on real-life projects and cases throughout the course, learning the importance of communicating findings to different constituents.

DA301.title: Diagnostic Analytics
DA301.description: This course takes descriptive data a step further by examining the relationships between variables through root cause analysis. Students will learn current tools and techniques that allow analysts to explain why the patterns are observed in data and discover relationships between two or more attributes of the data.

DA302W.title: Predictive Analytics
DA302W.description: Helps students learn to predict what will happen in future events based on historical data. Students will learn how to properly examine problem contexts to use the most appropriate method to develop the best predictive model as well as how to evaluate their results and interpret findings to users at different levels of an organization.

DA305.title: Data Ethics and Privacy
DA305.description: Cultivates awareness of ethical, privacy, and security rules and standards to guide how to use and analyze data and communicate the findings. The course will emphasize ethics at various stages of data analytics, including the communication of the implications of data analysis to stakeholders, how data is collected and stored, as well as how it is analyzed and presented to different stakeholders.

DA401.title: Prescriptive Analytics
DA401.description: Introduces students to how data analytics assists in making decisions and advocating for a course of action. Helps students learn to develop a set of viable decision options, rank those decision options to create alternative courses of action, and achieve an optimal decision.

DA402W.title: Qualitative Analytics
DA402W.description: Offers an overview of data analytics techniques for non-numeric data (e.g., text, videos, or images). Students will explore methodological reasons for a qualitative rather than a quantitative approach, and the underlying challenges with this type of data, depending on the hypothesis or research question. A strong background in statistics is required for this course.

DA475.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone I
DA475.description: This course allows students to demonstrate their ability to use industry or organization data to develop a descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analysis. This portion of the capstone addresses the understanding of the industry data, project scope, data journalism, and descriptive analysis.

DA476.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone II
DA476.description: This course continues the industry project (assigned in DA 475) and the remaining three-part analysis of organization-specific analysis (diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive).

DA497B.title: Analytics in Business
DA497B.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in business contexts, including data-driven decision-making and performance optimization in areas such as finance, management information systems, marketing, international business, accounting, and economics.

DA497E.title: Analytics in Engineering
DA497E.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in engineering, with a focus on system optimization, process improvement, and predictive modeling in engineering problems.

DA497S.title: Analytics in Science
DA497S.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in natural sciences, covering topics like experimental data analysis, statistical modeling, and simulation in scientific research.

DART202.title: 2D Digital Arts & Computer Graphics
DART202.description: Introduces 2D digital imaging techniques and concepts for the production of original art and design using graphics software.
DART202.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

DART203.title: 3D Digital Art & Design Fundamentals
DART203.description: Introduces 3D foundational skills for producing images, videos, objects, and interactive real-time virtual spaces with 3D software.

DART204.title: Animation Fundamentals
DART204.description: Introduces time-based animation fundamentals along with core skills and knowledge necessary for producing animated work.

DART206.title: Web Design and Visual Web Development
DART206.description: Introduces essential techniques and concepts of modern web design, focusing on how visual graphics and layout contribute to user experience.

DART300.title: Digital Portfolio Elements
DART300.description: An intermediate level studio course in which students develop digital art and design work that promotes creative thinking and problem-based learning in producing digital media projects to be included in their digital portfolio.

DART412.title: Portfolio Design and Professional Practices
DART412.description: This course emphasizes the development of presentation skills for digital artists in audience/client interactions.

DIGIT410.title: Data Visualization
DIGIT410.description: Presents techniques and software used for data visualization. Students will be introduced to complex data sets and learn how to present findings in interactive and innovative ways.

DIGIT430.title: Simulations of Human Behavior
DIGIT430.description: Students will develop an understanding of the systems, processes, tools, and implications of this field.
DIGIT430.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite 3 credits of programming and 3 credits of mathematics

DMD100.title: Digital Multimedia Design Foundations
DMD100.description: This course introduces students to concepts, skills, language and principles of practice in art and design, communication, and information sciences.
DMD100.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

DMD300.title: Digital Multimedia Design Studio
DMD300.description: In this course students synthesize concepts, theories, and applications acquired in introductory courses and think critically about their professional objectives.
DMD300.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite DMD 100 and 9 credits from the following list: IST 140, IST 250, COMM 230W, COMM 215, DART 202, ART 211Y C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

DMD400.title: Digital Multimedia Design Capstone
DMD400.description: In this capstone, students develop portfolio projects by applying creative production concepts, tools, and approaches to a contemporary issue.
DMD400.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite DMD 100andDMD 300 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

EARTH103N.title: Earth in the Future: Predicting Climate Change and Its Impacts Over the Next Century
EARTH103N.description: Climate predictions for the coming century are utilized to examine potential impacts on regions, sectors of society, and natural ecosystems.
EARTH103N.prerequisites_raw: GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

EARTH104N.title: Climate, Energy, and Our Future
EARTH104N.description: This course presents the past, present, and possible future response of Earth's climate to human energy use.

EARTH107N.title: Coastal Processes, Hazards, and Society
EARTH107N.description: Outcomes include the processes responsible for formation, diversity, and evolution of coastal landscapes; socioeconomic and policy responses to changes in coastal regions.

EARTH109.title: The Fundamentals of Shale Energy Development
EARTH109.description: Energy is a critical component of modern society, yet we face significant challenges associated with balancing energy demands, energy security, environmental sustainability, and stable economics with sound regulations and policy. Unconventional energy development from shale formations has been a game changer for the fossil fuel industry over the past decade and is projected to continue to grow over the next several decades.

EARTH111.title: Water: Science and Society
EARTH111.description: Students will investigate water behavior and occurrence, and its relevance to life, human activities, politics, and society.

EBF200.title: Introduction to Energy and Earth Sciences Economics
EBF200.description: Resource use decisions and their effect on local, national, and global development.
EBF200.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

EBF301.title: Global Finance for the Earth, Energy, and Materials Industries
EBF301.description: The aim of this course is to introduce fundamental concepts of financial management and illustrate their global applications.

EBF483.title: Introduction to Electricity Markets
EBF483.description: Covers the structure of the electricity industry, regulatory institutions that oversee the industry, and the new market institutions that have been put into place since electricity restructuring.
EBF483.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite EBF 200 and MATH 140 and EBF 301 and (EBF 472 or STAT 200 or STAT 401 or ECON 106 or SCM 200 )

ECON102.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON102.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.
ECON102.prerequisites_raw: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

ECON104.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
ECON104.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

ECON106.title: Statistical Foundations for Econometrics
ECON106.description: Basic statistical concepts used in economics. Topics include probability distributions, expectations, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation, and simple regression. Students who have completed ECON 306 may not schedule this course.
ECON106.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ECON302.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
ECON302.description: Allocation of resources and distribution of income within various market structures, with emphasis on analytical tools.
ECON302.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ECON 102 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ECON304.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
ECON304.description: Analysis of forces that determine the level of aggregate economic activity.
ECON304.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ECON 104 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ECON306.title: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON306.description: The implementation of statistical techniques to analyze data and address economic questions. Econometric results are produced and assessed.
ECON306.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ECON 106 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ECON315.title: Labor Economics
ECON315.description: Economic analysis of employment, earnings, and the labor market; labor relations; related government policies.

ECON333.title: International Economics
ECON333.description: Why nations trade, barriers to trade, balance of payments adjustment and exchange rate determination, eurocurrency markets, and trade-related institutions.

ECON342.title: Industrial Organization
ECON342.description: Focuses on the study of markets with imperfect competition.

ECON351.title: Money and Banking
ECON351.description: Money, credit, commercial and central banking, financial intermediaries, treasury operations, monetary theory and policy, and foreign exchange. Students who have already taken ECON 451 may not schedule this course.

ECON402.title: Decision Making and Strategy in Economics
ECON402.description: Development and application of the tools for decision making under uncertainty and for game theoretic analysis of economic problems.

ECON425.title: Economics of Public Expenditures
ECON425.description: Analytic and policy aspects of public expenditure decisions; applications from areas of contemporary public interest.

ECON428.title: Environmental Economics
ECON428.description: Environmental pollution, the market economy, and optimal resource allocation; alternative control procedures; levels of environmental protection and public policy.

ECON433.title: Advanced International Trade Theory and Policy
ECON433.description: Causes/consequences of trade; effects of tariffs and quotas; strategic trade policy; political economy of trade restrictions and other topics.

ECON434.title: International Finance and Open Economy Macroeconomics
ECON434.description: Trade balance movements, exchange rate determination; monetary and fiscal policies in open economies; international policy coordination; the world monetary system.

ECON471.title: Growth and Development
ECON471.description: Problems of capital formation, institutional considerations, theories of economic growth.

EE211.title: Electrical Circuits and Power Distribution
EE211.description: D.C. and A.C. circuits, transformers, single and three-phase distribution systems, A.C. motors and generators.

EGEE101.title: Energy and the Environment
EGEE101.description: Energy utilization and technological development, energy resources, conversion and consequences on the local and global environment, and future energy alternatives.
EGEE101.prerequisites_raw: GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

EGEE102.title: Energy Conservation for Environmental Protection
EGEE102.description: Exposure to energy efficiency in day-to-day life to save money and energy, and thereby protect the environment.
EGEE102.prerequisites_raw: GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

EGEE120.title: Oil: International Evolution
EGEE120.description: Survey of the commercial development of the world petroleum industry from various international, historical, business, and cultural perspectives.

EGEE299.title: Foreign Studies
EGEE299.description: Courses offered in foreign countries by individual or group instruction.

EGEE401.title: Energy in a Changing World
EGEE401.description: Energy is in transition, with increased international energy demand and increasing environmental pressures. Energy transitions, approaches, and outcomes are addressed.

EGEE495.title: Internship
EGEE495.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.

EME432.title: Energy Policy
EME432.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.
EME432.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite EBF 200andEGEE 120andPLSC 490 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

EME444.title: Global Energy Enterprise
EME444.description: Industry perspective on the resources, technologies, engineering approaches, and externalities involved in satisfying worldwide energy demand profitably and sustainably.
EME444.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ECON 104andEGEE 102 andEGEE 120 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

EME460.title: Geo-Resource Evaluation and Investment Analysis
EME460.description: The course covers engineering evaluation of geo-resources, present value and rate of return analysis, mineral property and reserve estimation, and cost estimation and engineering economy concepts applied to geo-resources including energy and minerals.

EME466.title: Energy and Sustainability in Society
EME466.description: Provides the culminating experience for Energy and Sustainability Policy majors through an individualized inquiry-based capstone project in which students tackle the wicked problems of sustainability they see and experience in their own communities.
EME466.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite To be taken only after all other courses have been successfully completed C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

EMSC240N.title: Energy and Sustainability in Contemporary Culture
EMSC240N.description: Critical evaluation of selected media (e.g., books, film) in contemporary culture on topics related to energy and sustainability.

EMSC302.title: Orientation to Energy and Sustainability Policy
EMSC302.description: Orientation to goals of the Energy and Sustainability Policy program and resources available to help students succeed.
EMSC302.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ENG202C.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
ENG202C.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
ENG202C.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

ENGL15.title: Rhetoric and Composition
ENGL15.description: An intensive, rhetorically based experience in reading and writing that will prepare you both to understand the communications that surround you and to succeed in your own communication efforts.
ENGL15.prerequisites_raw: c or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better

ENGL192.title: The Literature of Fantasy
ENGL192.description: Literature(s) of fantasy from early forms through a variety of contemporary traditions.

ENGL202A.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Social Sciences
ENGL202A.description: Introduces students to the types of writing that social scientists typically do in the workplace, including research proposals, proper citation practices, literature reviews, and research reports.
ENGL202A.prerequisites_raw: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

ENGL202B.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Humanities
ENGL202B.description: Instruction in writing persuasive arguments about significant issues in the humanities.
ENGL202B.prerequisites_raw: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

ENGL202C.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
ENGL202C.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
ENGL202C.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

ENGL202D.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
ENGL202D.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
ENGL202D.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30) andfourth-semester standing GWS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

ENGL215.title: Introduction to Article Writing
ENGL215.description: Written exercises in, and a study of, the principles of article writing; practice in the writing of specific articles.

ENGL245.title: Introduction to LGBTQ Studies
ENGL245.description: Learn about the dominant themes in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies, with an emphasis on both literary and cultural studies. This course explores the history of modern, Western ideas about sexual identity as manifested in literature, theatre, film, and other narrative forms of popular culture.

ENGL30.title: Honors Freshman Composition
ENGL30.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles. Enriched by more rigorous requirements (longer papers, additional research component where the student is required to cite and engage critical sources and conversations). Participation requirements are also enhanced, making for a richer honors experience.
ENGL30.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ENGL418.title: Advanced Technical Writing and Editing
ENGL418.description: Preparing and editing professional papers for subject specialists and for others interested in careers as writers or editors.

ENGL419.title: Advanced Business Writing
ENGL419.description: Preparing and editing reports and presentations common to business, industry, and government.
ENGL419.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ENGL420.title: Writing for the Web
ENGL420.description: Analysis and composition of informative, persuasive, and "creative" Web texts, based on rhetorical principles; no prior Web writing experience required.

ENGL478.title: Grant Writing
ENGL478.description: A successful grant writer achieves confidence with hands-on practice, mastering the underlying principles of effective research and outreach; feasible and complete content-generation; and the writing of precise, clear, audience-centered prose.

ENGL50.title: Introduction to Creative Writing
ENGL50.description: Practice and criticism in the reading, analysis, and composition of fiction, nonfiction, and poetry writing.

ENT317.title: Turfgrass Insect Pest Management
ENT317.description: Introduction to entomology and management of insect pests of cold- and warm-season turfgrass.

ENTR300.title: Principles of Entrepreneurship
ENTR300.description: Overview of the fundamental principles and processes of entrepreneurship, including idea generation and opportunity analysis.
ENTR300.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211,ECON 102 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ENTR320.title: Entrepreneurship and New Venture Creation
ENTR320.description: Explores the process for starting and growing a new venture, including the development of a business plan.
ENTR320.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENTR 300 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ENTR400.title: Financing Entrepreneurial Ventures
ENTR400.description: Overview of alternative forms of financing, including seed capital, valuing a company, going public, partnerships, and acquisitions.
ENTR400.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 243orBLAW 243;ENTR 320,FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

ETI300W.title: Development and Documentation of Enterprise Web
ETI300W.description: Students will draw upon their prior experience in databases, networks, and programming to understand how cloud-based infrastructure solutions are built, the possible choices an analyst will have, and the written communication needed in order to convey these design choices to others.

ETI301.title: Information and Organizations
ETI301.description: Overview of organizational structures and functions. Includes information processing and analytic perspectives of organizations.

ETI302.title: IT Project Management
ETI302.description: Exploration and application of the basic concepts, methodologies, and tools of project management in the field of information sciences and technology.

ETI420.title: Fundamentals of Systems and Enterprise Integration
ETI420.description: Introductory course on integration of information technology into different venues, including the planning, development, and implementation of the integration.
ETI420.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (C or better inETI 301andETI 302)and (C or better inIST 240orIST 242)

ETI421.title: Advanced Enterprise Integration: Technologies and Applications
ETI421.description: Advanced course on the integration of information technology into systems applications.
ETI421.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inETI 420

ETI435.title: Enterprise Analytics
ETI435.description: Explores topics including enterprise-level analytics, big data, and analytics case studies in health care, manufacturing, HR, and financial services.

ETI461.title: Database Management and Administration
ETI461.description: A study of advanced topics in database management systems that are fundamental to effective administration of modern enterprise information systems.

ETI463.title: Distributed Database Management Systems
ETI463.description: Focuses on the design and system issues related to distributed database systems.

FIN301.title: Corporation Finance
FIN301.description: Nature of finance function; risk and return concepts; working capital; dividend policies; mergers; security markets; acquisition and management of corporate capital; analysis of operations; forecasting capital requirements; raising capital; and planning profits. Available to baccalaureate students only.

FIN330.title: Personal Financial Planning
FIN330.description: Developing financial plans including cash budgets, credit purchases, investments, and insurance.
FIN330.prerequisites_raw: Note Third-semester standing or permission of instructor.

FIN416.title: Intermediate Financial Modeling
FIN416.description: The course focuses primarily on the development of spreadsheet applications and the use of the case method to apply decision-making procedures to real-world problems in finance areas.

FIN420.title: Investment and Portfolio Analysis
FIN420.description: Investment and risk, types of security investments, sources of investment information, the broker, the stock market, portfolio management.
FIN420.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

FIN430.title: Estate Planning
FIN430.description: Liquidity planning, titling and transfer of property, trusts, federal unified tax system, gifting, incapacity planning, legal documents.

FIN450.title: Retirement Planning
FIN450.description: Retirement planning: qualified and non-qualified plans, characteristics, provisions, regulations administration, application approach with case studies.

FIN451.title: Intermediate Financial Management
FIN451.description: Case studies are used to develop skills in solving a variety of financial management problems.
FIN451.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

FIN471.title: International Finance
FIN471.description: Financial decision-making in an international environment. Emphasis on topics relevant to small businesses and entrepreneurs.
FIN471.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

FIN491.title: Financial Planning Capstone
FIN491.description: Critical thinking and decision-making about personal financial planning topics in the context of the financial planning process.
FIN491.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite completion of first 15 credits of the certificate curriculum

FIN497.title: Use Cases in Financial Analytics
FIN497.description: 6â€“10 case studies demonstrating types of studies in financial analytics

GD110.title: User Experience Design: Concepts and Principles
GD110.description: Study foundational concepts and methodologies in User Experience (UX) design and thinking. The course will feature iterative design processes to employ basic management techniques in working with product stakeholders for digital planning practices.

GD210.title: User Interface Design and Prototyping
GD210.description: Apply knowledge in User Interface (UI) design and practice designing and prototyping compelling visual interfaces for multiple platforms - from websites to physical spaces to the nuanced interactions in mobile and wearable environments.

GEOG128.title: Geography of International Affairs
GEOG128.description: Contemporary international affairs in their geographical setting; geographic elements in the development of national power, political groupings, and international disputes.

GEOG1N.title: Global Parks and Sustainability
GEOG1N.description: This course uses parks and protected areas â€” both in the U.S. and globally â€” as a framework for exploring broad themes of sustainability, conservation, and socio-ecological systems.

GEOG2N.title: Apocalyptic Geographies: How can we prevent the end of the world?
GEOG2N.description: Explores various visions of the apocalypse and their relevance for addressing major contemporary social, ecological, and economic issues.
