These issues include global climate change, nuclear war, the growing refugee crisis, the breakdown of democratic governance, economic recession, and forms of everyday violence and social fracture.

GEOG30N.title: Environment and Society in a Changing World
GEOG30N.description: Introduction to the relationships between humans and the natural environment, in addition to the theories and methods that geographers employ in addressing them.
GEOG30N.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

GEOG3N.title: Food and the Future Environment
GEOG3N.description: Introduces students to the multiple connections of people and the environment through the dynamics of food and the places where it is produced, processed, and consumed.

GEOG430.title: Human Use of Environment
GEOG430.description: The human use of resources and ecosystems and social causes and consequences of environmental degradation in different parts of the world; development of environmental policy and management strategies.

GEOG431.title: Geography of Water Resources
GEOG431.description: Designed for students to understand the natural processes of aquatic ecosystems, management of water resources, and threats to sustaining water quantity and quality, for all types of freshwater surface, groundwater, rivers, lakes, wetlands.

GEOG432.title: Energy Policy
GEOG432.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.
GEOG432.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite EBF 200andEGEE 120andPLSC 490 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

GEOG438W.title: Human Dimensions of Global Warming
GEOG438W.description: Human dimensions of global environmental change: human causes; human adaptations; and policy implications of global warming.
GEOG438W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (EARTH 2orGEOG 10orMETEO 3) andGEOG 30N C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

GEOG6N.title: Maps and the Geospatial Revolution
GEOG6N.description: Explores the fundamentals of cartography, geographic information science, and associated technologies through mapping and spatial analysis to answer key human and environmental problems.

HCDD113.title: Foundations of Human-Centered Design and Development
HCDD113.description: Examines the relationship between physical capabilities, cognitive and social models, and philosophical issues pertinent to human-centered analysis, design and development work.
HCDD113.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

HCDD311.title: Object-Oriented Design and Software Applications
HCDD311.description: Introduction to object-oriented applications, including applications in an Object-Oriented Design (OOD) language or OOD languages.
HCDD311.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242orCMPSC 221

HCDD331.title: Foundations of Human-Centered Design
HCDD331.description: Interdisciplinary survey of topics and methods related to the human-centered design use and usability of information systems.
HCDD331.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 240orIST 242

HCDD361.title: Application Development Design Studio II
HCDD361.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
HCDD361.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Grade of C or better inIST 311 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

HCDD411.title: Distributed-Object Computing
HCDD411.description: Introduction to distributed-object computing and its use in client/server and real-world computing applications.
HCDD411.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

HCDD412.title: The Engineering of Complex Software Systems
HCDD412.description: Introduction to the engineering of complex software systems, including software system specification, design and implementation, integration and test, and evolution.
HCDD412.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

HCDD413.title: Usability Engineering
HCDD413.description: This course addresses activities in the system development process that ensure usability. It considers the emerging concept of usability, requirements gathering and analysis, activity design, information design, interaction design, documentation design, user testing, and usability evaluation.
HCDD413.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 331

HDFS129.title: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
HDFS129.description: Introduction to psychosocial and family development at all stages of the individual and family life cycle.
HDFS129.prerequisites_raw: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

HDFS229.title: Infant and Child Development
HDFS229.description: Theory, research, and methods of social/behavioral/biological sciences related to developmental processes and intervention during infancy and childhood.
HDFS229.prerequisites_raw: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

HDFS239.title: Adolescent Development
HDFS239.description: Social, behavioral, and biological development and intervention throughout adolescence.
HDFS239.prerequisites_raw: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

HDFS249N.title: Adult Development and Aging
HDFS249N.description: Physiological, psychological, and social development and intervention from young adulthood through old age.
HDFS249N.prerequisites_raw: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

HDFS250.title: Sexual Identity over the Life Span
HDFS250.description: Concepts of affectional and sexual orientation over life span, with emphasis on lesbian and gay male personal, family, and community adaptation.

HDFS254N.title: Reading Our Lives: Understanding Diversity and Human Development through Memoirs
HDFS254N.description: Students will explore the way people and their environments interact to influence human development through the integration of memoirs and other personal narratives, humanist themes and methods of inquiry, and social science theory and research.

HDFS301.title: Values and Ethics in Health and Human Development Professions
HDFS301.description: Examines bases for choices among values in personal and professional relations in human development processes and supporting services.

HDFS311.title: Human Development and Family Studies Interventions
HDFS311.description: Survey of individual and family formal and informal intervention efforts; historical and current perspectives and approaches.

HDFS312W.title: Empirical Inquiry in Human Development
HDFS312W.description: Introduction to the skills involved in critical thinking in general and the methods of empirical inquiry in particular.
HDFS312W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite a grade of C or better required inEDPSY 101orSTAT 200

HDFS315Y.title: Family Development
HDFS315Y.description: Family functions over the life course; family from a multidisciplinary perspective, emphasizing adaptation and change.
HDFS315Y.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HDFS 129 or3 credits in social, behavioral, or human biological sciences

HDFS411.title: The Helping Relationship
HDFS411.description: Theory and research related to interpersonal conditions which facilitate personal growth; intensive interpersonal competency training.
HDFS411.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (HDFS 311 andHDFS 312W)or 6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

HDFS414.title: Resolving Human Development and Family Problems
HDFS414.description: Strategies for, and roles of professional specialists in, the solution of problems in human development and family functioning.
HDFS414.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HDFS 312W and6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

HDFS418.title: Family Relationships
HDFS418.description: Dynamics of family interaction; effects of parenthood, sibling and intergeneration relationships on family solidarity.

HDFS428.title: Infant Development
HDFS428.description: Conceptual analysis, assessment, and empirical investigation of normal and deviant development, prenatal through first two years of life.

HDFS429.title: Advanced Child Development
HDFS429.description: Processes of development during childhood from birth to adolescence. Emphasis on theory, method, and empirical research.

HDFS433.title: Developmental Transition to Adulthood
HDFS433.description: Conceptual analysis and empirical investigation of interrelationships between developmental processes during the period of pubertal growth.

HDFS445.title: Development throughout Adulthood
HDFS445.description: Processes of development and change of behavior from early adulthood through old age, emphasizing theory, method, and empirical research.
HDFS445.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HDFS 249and (HDFS 312WorPSYCH 301W) and (PSYCH 200 orSTAT 200or 3 credits of statistics) and (6 credits in HDFS or PSYCH or SOC)

HDFS455.title: Development and Administration of Human Services Programs
HDFS455.description: Fundamentals of program development and administration of human service programs in community settings; emphasis given to program content, strategies, and the overall planning process.

HDFS490.title: Introduction to Internship Experience
HDFS490.description: Planning and preparation for field experience in human service setting. Analysis of human service system and arrangement of site.
HDFS490.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HDFS 312W; approval by internship coordinator. Prerequisite or concurrent HDFS 411

HDFS495A.title: Internship: Advanced Experience
HDFS495A.description: Full-time, one semester experiential training in human service settings.
HDFS495A.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HDFS 490 and HDFS 301 and HDFS 455 andpermission of internship director

HDFS495B.title: Internship: Advanced Project
HDFS495B.description: Implementation of internship projects or scholarly paper.

HIST101.title: The Roman Republic and Empire
HIST101.description: History of the Roman Republic and Empire from the origins of Rome to the disintegration of the Empire.

HIST103.title: History of Madness, Mental Illness, and Psychiatry
HIST103.description: Examines the ideas that have shaped European and American perceptions of madness, insanity, and mental illness; the changing experiences of those afflicted; the development of those professions designed to look after those deemed mad, insane, and mentally ill; and the social and cultural assumptions behind treatments, policies, and public opinions.

HIST107.title: Medieval Europe
HIST107.description: Covers the development of political, judicial, and diplomatic institutions; the role of religion as a significant element of medieval society; the development of royal houses; and changes in economic and social life of medieval Europe.

HIST109.title: Introduction to U.S. Environmental History
HIST109.description: Explores changing relationships between humans and the natural world, while examining American landscape, environmental activism, and the development of ideas about nature. Major themes include the natural context of American history and the socially constructed and historically contingent knowledge about nature.

HIST111.title: Introduction to U.S. Food History
HIST111.description: Analyzes the history of agriculture and food production in the U.S., examining consumption patterns, the food industry, marketing, and regulation. Also explores the impact of food systems on human well-being and addresses issues of sustainability, productivity, social effects, and environmental impacts.

HIST117.title: Women in United States History
HIST117.description: Focuses on key historical developments in womenâ€™s history, including actual experiences as members of a class, a race, and an ethnic community; the progress women have made as individuals, workers, and citizens; as well as the opposition they have faced.

HIST120N.title: History of Modern Europe Since 1789
HIST120N.description: Political, social, and ideological developments; origin and impact of two World Wars; totalitarianism and democracy; changing role in the world.

HIST122.title: History of Science I
HIST122.description: Surveys the history of science and scientific inquiry on a global scale from the Neolithic period to the 19th century.

HIST130.title: Introduction to the Civil War Era, 1848 through 1877
HIST130.description: Survey of the causes and consequences of America's deadliest conflict, the Civil War, from the end of the U.S.-Mexican War in 1848 through the end of Reconstruction in 1877.

HIST139.title: The World at War: 1914â€“1918
HIST139.description: Explores the military and political elements of World War I along with its profound impact on societies; topics include battle dynamics, state policies, and life on the home front â€” labor unrest, food insecurity, welfare efforts, and refugees.

HIST144.title: The World at War: 1939â€“1945
HIST144.description: In-depth study of the origins and conduct of World War II. Political and economic aspects as well as military.

HIST155.title: American Business History
HIST155.description: This course examines major developments in the history of modern American business and industry from the colonial period to the present.
HIST155.prerequisites_raw: GH and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Humanities (GH) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

HIST165.title: Islamic States, Societies, and Cultures c. 600-1500
HIST165.description: Introduces students to the history and culture of the Islamic world; develops a historical framework for understanding developments in religious and legal thought and practice, science, medicine, and technology, philosophy, and the arts.

HIST179.title: Latin American since 1820
HIST179.description: Examines the history of modern Latin America, including the geographic and political development of the region, the development of various economic models, and the widespread extraction of labor focusing on African slavery and Indigenous exploitation.

HIST181.title: Introduction to the Middle East
HIST181.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

HIST184.title: Society and Culture in the Pacific War
HIST184.description: Looks at the origins, nature, and consequences of World War II in the Pacific; assesses different nations, political movements, ideologies, and empires that clashed across Asia-Pacific from 1931 to 1945.

HIST193.title: Modern Iran
HIST193.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

HIST20.title: American Civilization to 1877
HIST20.description: An historical survey of the American experience from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War and Reconstruction.

HIST21.title: American Civilization Since 1877
HIST21.description: An historical survey of the American experience from the emergence of urban-industrial society in the late nineteenth century to the present.

HIST302W.title: Undergraduate Seminar
HIST302W.description: Involves a thematic or topical investigation with an emphasis on historical criticism and analysis; students will pursue the study of one historical topic in detail in this writing intensive course.

HIST426.title: The Holocaust
HIST426.description: In-depth study of the history of the Holocaust in Europe that puts special emphasis on primary sources.

HIST441.title: Revolutionary America, 1753â€“1783
HIST441.description: Explores the forces in Great Britain and America that caused withdrawal of thirteen colonies from the British Empire and the Revolutionary War.
HIST441.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HIST 020, 3 additional credits in history

HIST447.title: Recent American History
HIST447.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

HIST450.title: Constitutional History since 1877
HIST450.description: Provides an understanding of the Constitutional developments from laissez-faire to the welfare state; imperialism, war, internationalism; the contemporary court, civil liberties, and civil rights.
HIST450.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Prerequisites:HIST 020orHIST 021, plus 3 additional credits in history or political science.

HIST453.title: American Environmental History
HIST453.description: The history of the ways Americans have used and thought about the environment since 1500.

HIST458Y.title: History of Work in America
HIST458Y.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

HIST473.title: The Contemporary Middle East
HIST473.description: Focuses on the political, economic, and social changes in Turkey, Iran, Israel, and the Arab countries in the twentieth century; explores the Arab-Israeli conflict.
HIST473.prerequisites_raw: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

HIST479.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
HIST479.description: Theories and types of imperialism; varied patterns of colonial administration; initial African responses; nationalism; decolonization and independence.
HIST479.prerequisites_raw: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

HIST486.title: China in Revolution
HIST486.description: Explores the complex social and cultural history of modern China from 1900 to the present, including the formation of the modern nation-state, the development of communism, and the relationship between elite and popular culture.
HIST486.prerequisites_raw: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

HLS201.title: Introduction to Homeland Security
HLS201.description: An introduction to homeland security and defense, with a focus on policy, legal issues, organization, and administration.

HLS306.title: Introduction to Crisis and Emergency Management
HLS306.description: An introduction to emergency management in mitigating, preparing for, responding to, and recovering from hazards.

HLS475.title: Critical Infrastructure Protection
HLS475.description: Provides knowledge about protection of critical infrastructure as an aspect of homeland security

HLS476.title: Homeland Security Intelligence
HLS476.description: The Homeland Security Intelligence course provides a depth of knowledge of key intelligence issues for homeland security professionals.

HLS483.title: Seminar in National Security Policy
HLS483.description: This course will examine the inter-relationship of foreign, military and economic policy.

HORT101.title: Horticultural Science
HORT101.description: Introduction to horticulture with an emphasis on plant domestication, morphology, classification, world food crops, commodities, gardens, propagation, and agrochemicals. The course content deals with the fundamental concepts and specialty areas, which contribute not only to the science and technology involved in horticulture but also to the art.

HPA101.title: Introduction to Health Services Organization
HPA101.description: Examination of the social, political, historic, and scientific factors in the development and organization of health services.

HPA200.title: An Introduction to Data in the Health Care System
HPA200.description: This course examines the broad topic of data and health care decisions, particularly how to be an astute consumer of data about health, the health care system, and health policy.

HPA210.title: Health Care Payment
HPA210.description: This course covers basic concepts and issues related to health insurance and payment for health care providers.

HPA211.title: Financial Decisions in Health Care Organizations
HPA211.description: An introduction to financial and economic information to make decisions in health care organizations.

HPA301W.title: Health Services Policy Issues
HPA301W.description: Analysis of major issues in health services delivery in hospitals, medical practice, public health, mental health, and health professional education.

HPA310.title: Health Care and Medical Needs
HPA310.description: Health care from an individual, family, and community standpoint illustrated with specific diseases and health problems.

HPA311.title: Population Health and Health Care
HPA311.description: This course covers fundamental theories, concepts, issues, and strategies related to a population health approach to health and health services.

HPA332.title: Health Systems Management
HPA332.description: This course provides you with an overview of how health care institutions are organized and governed, the role of the management staff, and the management systems designed for their efficient and effective operation.
HPA332.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HPA 101,HPA 211 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

HPA390W.title: Professional Development in Health Policy and Administration
HPA390W.description: Development of personal understanding and professional skills to prepare students for future employment or study in health policy and administration.

HPA395.title: Field Experience in Health Policy and Administration
HPA395.description: Professional field experience providing opportunities to apply skills and knowledge in health care setting.
HPA395.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite HPA 301,HPA 310,HPA 332,HPA 390W Full-Time Equivalent Course Full-time equivalent (FTE) classes have been approved to be offered as full time regardless of the number of credits the class is worth.

HPA430.title: Health Care Leadership
HPA430.description: This course provides an opportunity to students to learn about the challenges of leadership in health care.

HPA438.title: Culturally Competent Health Services for Diverse Populations
HPA438.description: This course examines the broad concept of diversity and its impact on health care, particularly on rendering services to patients from diverse groups and about the challenges health care professionals face serving diverse populations. Diversity includes many factors, such as age, ethnicity, race, religion, physical and mental disability, class, gender, and sexual orientation. To eradicate health disparities and improve health outcomes, students will explore effective and culturally appropriate strategies and interventions to deliver health care to diverse health care consumers.

HPA440.title: Principles of Epidemiology
HPA440.description: Theory of epidemiology and significant case studies. Potential application to health care.
HPA440.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (BBH 310orBIOL 230WorHPA 311) and (STAT 200orSTAT 250) Note This course is typically offered asBBH 440

HPA442.title: Long-Term Care Management
HPA442.description: Management and policy issues for institutional, community, and home settings for chronic care services.

HPA455.title: Strategic Planning and Marketing for Health Services
HPA455.description: Introduction to principles and methods of strategic planning and marketing.

HPA460.title: Human Resource Management in Health Care Organizations
HPA460.description: Foundations of human resource management applied to health care organizations, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, and community health organizations.

HPA475.title: Health Care Quality
HPA475.description: This course covers the basic principles and techniques of quality management in health care, including the definition, measurement, and uses of data for improving the quality of health and health services.

HPA57.title: Consumer Choices in Health Care
HPA57.description: Introduction to consumers' role in health care decisions, including health benefits, physician and hospital choice, and end-of-life choices.

HSS497H.title: Analytics in Humanities and the Social Sciences
HSS497H.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in humanities and social sciences, including text analysis, thematic and content analysis, statistical modeling, regression analysis, media analytics, program evaluation, trend analysis, text mining, demography, ethnography, simulation, and the interpretation of cultural data in fields such as education, psychology, sociology, political science, communication, cultural studies, history, and language arts.

IB303.title: International Business Operations
IB303.description: A survey of the major aspects of international business environment and operations with an emphasis on the cultural dimension.
IB303.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Fifth-semester standing C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better. IL The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Integrative Studies (IL) requirement.

IST110.title: Information, People, and Technology
IST110.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

IST140.title: Introduction to Application Development
IST140.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
IST140.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level of Math 21 in the mathematics placement test. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST210.title: Organization of Data
IST210.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.
IST210.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST220.title: Networking and Telecommunications
IST220.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.
IST220.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST230.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
IST230.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
IST230.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST242.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
IST242.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
IST242.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST250.title: Introduction to Web Design and Development
IST250.description: Introduction to how the World Wide Web utilizes emerging technologies. Students acquire a conceptual understanding of constructing websites.
IST250.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST256.title: Programming for the Web
IST256.description: This course will provide students with the knowledge and skills to create both basic and more dynamic web-based content pages and applications.

IST261.title: Application Development Design Studio I
IST261.description: Introductory design and development studio course for IST and SRA students.
IST261.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST402.title: Emerging Issues and Technologies
IST402.description: Introduction to emerging issues, technology forecasting and analysis; overview of emerging issues and leading technologies in IST and how they impact information systems, users, the IT labor force and society.

IST423.title: Enterprise Information Management and Storage Architecture
IST423.description: This course provides in-depth study of the concepts, issues, and technologies associated with the complex world of enterprise information and storage architecture.

IST432.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
IST432.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.
IST432.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite IST 301orSRA 231 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

IST440W.title: Information Sciences and Technology Integration and Problem Solving
IST440W.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.
IST440W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 202CorENGL 202Dand seventh-semester standing (this course is intended for seniors)

IST452.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Privacy and Security
IST452.description: Exploration of legal, regulatory, public policy, and ethical issues related to security and privacy for information technology professionals in public institutions, private enterprise, and IT services.

IST453.title: Legal, Regulatory, Policy Environment of Cyber Forensics
IST453.description: Legal, regulatory, and public policy environment of computer and network forensics that constrain investigatory and monitoring activities in computer and network environments.
IST453.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite IST 110and sixth-semester standing or higher

IST495.title: Internship
IST495.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
IST495.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

JST193.title: Modern Iran
JST193.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

KINES203.title: Medical Terminology for Allied Health Professionals
KINES203.description: Comprehensive review of terms related to functions, disorders, diagnosis, and treatment of body systems related to physical activity and movement.

LA201W.title: Experiential Learning Portfolio
LA201W.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

LA402.title: Fundraising Leadership: Building a Strong Base
LA402.description: Focused on the fundamentals of fundraising and leadership, including communications, management of events and people, and stewardship.

LA404.title: Careers in Fundraising and Development
LA404.description: Guides students through an introduction to the fundraising/advancement profession, including a review of the history and emergence of the profession. Touches on key issues such as professional ethics and the legal environment of the field.

LA496.title: Independent Studies
LA496.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

LER464.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
LER464.description: Surveys the theory, research, and practice related to the communication processes by which individuals in groups and organizations exercise influence, whether or not they occupy positions of acknowledged leadership.

LHR100.title: Exploring Work and Employment
LHR100.description: Introductory analysis of the employment relationship and the interrelated interests of management, workers, unions, and the public.

LHR136.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
LHR136.description: Employment relations and legislative and policy responses to labor force issues of racial and gender inequality.

LHR136W.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
LHR136W.description: To accomplish the goals of the course, students will participate in a variety of in-class and out-of-class exercises designed to expose them to issues of inequality generally, and more specifically, to inequalities relating to employment. Activities are designed to connect real world experiences to class readings and discussion.

LHR136Y.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
LHR136Y.description: This course will ask how race and gender affect work in the contemporary United States.

LHR201.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
LHR201.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

LHR202.title: Understanding Employee Behavior
LHR202.description: The course will be offered at an introductory level. It is designed to encourage students to explore individual and group behavior at work.

LHR304.title: Labor and Employment Relations Fundamentals
LHR304.description: The course surveys the main elements of modern labor and employment relations systems in the U.S. and beyond.

LHR305.title: Human Resources Fundamentals
LHR305.description: This course will provide students with an opportunity to understand and apply important concepts concerning human resources in the workplace.

LHR312.title: Research Methods in Labor Studies and Employment Relations
LHR312.description: The objective of this course is to enhance students' abilities to use a range of methodologies to evaluate and conduct research in the field of employment relations and human resource management.

LHR400.title: Comparative Employment Relations Systems
LHR400.description: Analysis of structure and elements of employment relations systems in developed and developing areas.

LHR401.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
LHR401.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.

LHR403.title: International Human Resource Studies
LHR403.description: Course exploring human resource management from an international perspective.

LHR409.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
LHR409.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

LHR424.title: Employment Compensation
LHR424.description: Development and management of employee compensation systems.
LHR424.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite LHR 201and sixth-semester standing C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

LHR426.title: Staffing and Training Strategies in Organizations
LHR426.description: This course focuses on the theory and practice of human resource staffing and training in organizations.

LHR427.title: Understanding Business Processes for LHR Professionals
LHR427.description: This course examines human resource management (HRM) and employment relations (ER) from a strategic perspective embedded in a complex and evolving organizational system.

LHR428.title: Total Rewards
LHR428.description: This course requires students to learn the link between company's strategy and compensation, and understand core policies necessary to develop effective compensation systems.

LHR434.title: Advanced Collective Bargaining and Contract Administration
LHR434.description: This course examines, at an advanced level, the theory, practice, and impact of the major phases of union organizing, collective bargaining, and contract administration.

LHR435.title: Labor Relations in the Public Sector
LHR435.description: Upon completing this course, students should be able to identify the legal frameworks that govern collective bargaining between employers and unions in federal, state and local governments.

LHR437.title: Workplace Dispute Resolution
LHR437.description: This course examines dispute resolution procedures in unionized and nonunion workplaces.

LHR444.title: Workplace Safety and Health: Principles and Practices
LHR444.description: The role of employees, unions, employers, and government in dealing with work-related safety and health issues.

LHR458.title: History of Work in America
LHR458.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

LHR458Y.title: History of Work in America
LHR458Y.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

LHR460.title: Ethics in the Workplace
LHR460.description: Explores ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.
LHR460.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite LHR 100or fifth-semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

LHR464.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
LHR464.description: Theory-and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

LHR465.title: Collective Decision-Making
LHR465.description: Application of theories of decision making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

LHR466.title: Labor Union Structure, Administration, and Governance
LHR466.description: Comprehensive analysis of American Labor Unions/Labor Organizations: how structured, administered, and governed as they pursue economic, social, political objectives.

LHR468.title: American Labor Unions
LHR468.description: Students will examine, debate and gain a fundamental understanding of the current state of the American labor movement.

LHR472.title: Work-Life Practices and Policies
LHR472.description: Explore the causes and consequences of conflicts between work, family, and other life commitments, and how these may be resolved.
LHR472.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite 3 credits of LHR C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MATH110.title: Techniques of Calculus I
MATH110.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
MATH110.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 022orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MATH140.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
MATH140.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
MATH140.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MATH141.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry II
MATH141.description: Derivatives, integrals, applications; sequences and series; analytic geometry; polar coordinates.
MATH141.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 140orMATH 140AorMATH 140BorMATH 140EorMATH 140GorMATH 140H C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MATH21.title: College Algebra I
MATH21.description: Quadratic equations; equation in quadratic form; word problems; graphing; algebraic fractions; negative and rational exponents; radicals.
MATH21.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 4or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination. C or better Students need to earn at least a C grade in each course taken to be eligible for the certificate.

MATH22.title: College Algebra II
MATH22.description: Relations, functions, graphs; polynomial, rational functions, graphs; word problems; nonlinear inequalities; inverse functions; exponential, logarithmic functions; conic sections; simultaneous equations.
MATH22.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MATH220.title: Matrices
MATH220.description: Systems of linear equations; matrix algebra; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; linear systems of differential equations.

MATH250.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH250.description: First- and second-order equations; special functions; Laplace transform solutions; higher order equations.

MATH26.title: Plane Trigonometry
MATH26.description: Trigonometric functions; solutions of triangles; trigonometric equations; identities.
MATH26.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 021or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

METEO101.title: Understanding Weather Forecasting
METEO101.description: Fundamental principles of synoptic and physical meteorology, satellite and radar imagery, and data analysis in the setting of mid-latitude weather forecasting.

METEO241.title: Fundamentals of Tropical Forecasting
METEO241.description: Applying atmospheric principles to the tropics, with an emphasis on the development, structure, prediction, and destructive impact of hurricanes.

METEO3.title: Introductory Meteorology
METEO3.description: Nontechnical treatment of fundamentals of modern meteorology and the effects of weather and climate.

METEO361.title: Fundamentals of Mesoscale Weather Forecasting
METEO361.description: Applying atmospheric principles to small-scale weather systems, with an emphasis on the conceptual modeling and short-range prediction of severe thunderstorms.

METEO410.title: Advanced Topics in Weather Forecasting
METEO410.description: Exploring highly specialized topics and techniques in weather forecasting that span from mesoscale to planetary spatial scales and short-term to long-range time scales.

METEO469.title: From Meteorology to Mitigation: Understanding Global Warming
METEO469.description: Examination of global warming and climate change: the basic science, projects, impacts, and approaches to mitigation.
METEO469.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite STAT 200orMATH 110orMATH 140 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MGMT100.title: Survey of Management
MGMT100.description: Introduction to organizational factors relevant to management processes, including leadership, motivation, job design, technology, organizational design and environments, systems, change.

MGMT301.title: Basic Management Concepts
MGMT301.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
MGMT301.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

MGMT321.title: Leadership and Motivation
MGMT321.description: Applies organizational behavior theories, concepts, and skills to leading and motivating individuals and groups.

MGMT331.title: Management and Organization
MGMT331.description: Designing organizations to effectively manage new technologies, structures, and people in changing global contexts.

MGMT341.title: Human Resource Management
MGMT341.description: Introduction to the strategic planning and implementation of human resource management, including staffing, development, appraisal, and rewards.

MGMT409.title: Project Management for Non-Business Majors
MGMT409.description: Covers the technical and people skills related to project management within a variety of organizational structures. Students learn the tools and concepts needed to successfully balance schedule, budget, and scope while managing risk and resources during the project life cycle. Leadership and teamwork skills are emphasized and practiced in a hands-on approach.

MGMT410.title: Project Management
MGMT410.description: Gain the ability to exert leadership in managing project teams, an understanding of people and behavioral skills, and the ability to effectively use computer-based scheduling and tracking software.

MGMT415.title: Project Portfolio Management and Organizations
MGMT415.description: An advanced course in project management focusing on portfolio planning and control within the context of specific organizational challenges.

MGMT418.title: Project Planning and Resource Management
MGMT418.description: Advanced course in project management focusing on a more in-depth approach to project planning and scheduling and resource management.

MGMT461.title: International Management
MGMT461.description: Examines issues of nations and cultures including motivation, communication, negotiation, leadership, ethics and social responsibility, and women in management.

MGMT471W.title: Strategic Management and Business Policy
MGMT471W.description: Study of strategic management and business policy formulation and implementation processes.
MGMT471W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MGMT 301,MKTG 301W,FIN 301,SCM 301 Note BA 422Wcan be substituted for this course C or better Students need to earn at least a C grade in each course taken to be eligible for the certificate.

MICRB106.title: Elementary Microbiology
MICRB106.description: A survey course in microbiology for non-majors, this course focuses on the roles of microbes in human health and disease, agriculture, biotechnology, and other areas of societal impact.
MICRB106.prerequisites_raw: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

MICRB107.title: Elementary Microbiology Laboratory
MICRB107.description: Selected techniques used to observe, identify, and count bacteria; effects of chemical and physical agents on microorganisms. The combination of MICRB 106 GN and 107 GN must be taken to receive General Education credit in biology.
MICRB107.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MICRB 106 GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

MIS204.title: Introduction to Business Information Systems
MIS204.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.

MIS250.title: Introduction to Problem-Solving with Spreadsheet Analysis and Information Systems Management
MIS250.description: This course explores the application of spreadsheet engineering concepts and principles of data management, business modeling, and reporting to business problems.

MIS301.title: Business Analytics
MIS301.description: This course investigates use of databases, basic data mining tools, social networking software, and advanced level of spreadsheet management for analysis of large amounts of data.

MIS336.title: Database Management Systems
MIS336.description: Theory and utilization of database management systems in organizations, including data modeling and applications development.

MIS390.title: Information Systems Management and Applications
MIS390.description: Specification, design and implementation of information systems directed at aiding decision-making in organizations.

MIS404.title: Introduction to ERP and Business Processes
MIS404.description: A problem-based, interdisciplinary course on Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) concepts to help you understand the integrated software modules used to run virtually all business processes in an organization. This course explains and demonstrates in detail how business processes such as sales logistics, production/material management, procurement, and human resources are supported in an ERP software package.
MIS404.source_program: Enterprise Resource Planning Certificate with SAP
MIS404.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MIS 204or first-level programming course or with permission from the program

MIS415.title: Social Media Management and Analytics
MIS415.description: In-depth analysis of social media management, digital marketing, SEO/M, and analytics of current digital business practices. Presents an analysis of current issues in digital marketing and the tools needed to assess those issues.

MIS447.title: Data Warehousing
MIS447.description: Using case studies in various business domains, exercises, and projects, this course presents practical dimensional modeling techniques, extract/transformation/load (ETL) logic, ETL design considerations, and report generation. Key concepts related to data warehousing, including dimensional table characteristics, fact table characteristics and granularity, types of dimensions, types of fact tables, dimension attribute hierarchies, consolidated fact tables, slowly changing dimension techniques, and multivalued dimensions and weighting factors are covered in the course.

MKTG301.title: Principles of Marketing
MKTG301.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting. Not available to students who have taken BA 303.
MKTG301.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30) and(ECON 102orECON 104) and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.)

MKTG301W.title: Principles of Marketing
MKTG301W.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting.
MKTG301W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030;ECON 102orECON 104;MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.

MKTG327.title: Retailing
MKTG327.description: Management of marketing institutions in distribution channels from producers to consumers. Emphasis on retail institutions: location, personnel, merchandising, control, promotion.
MKTG327.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG330.title: Consumer Behavior
MKTG330.description: Application of behavioral science concepts to the understanding of buyer behavior as a basis for marketing management decision-making.
MKTG330.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG342.title: Marketing Research
MKTG342.description: Research approaches, methods, and applications studied as a formal approach to problem-solving for marketing decisions.
MKTG342.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W;SCM 200orSTAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG422.title: Advertising and Sales Promotion Management
MKTG422.description: Perspectives and models of the key decisions involved in managing advertising and sales promotion campaigns.
MKTG422.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MKTG 330orMKTG 342 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG445.title: Global Marketing
MKTG445.description: Role of international marketing in the global environment; political, economic, geographic, historical, cultural conditions; developing and implementing international marketing strategies.
MKTG445.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG450W.title: Marketing Strategy
MKTG450W.description: Market-oriented problems of the firm; identification and selection of market opportunities; formulation of competitive strategies; marketing policies and programs.
MKTG450W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MKTG 330andMKTG 342 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG476.title: Sales Management
MKTG476.description: Application of modern management principles to field sales force planning, organization, and administration; selection, training, and compensation plans.
MKTG476.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MKTG 301WandMGMT 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

MKTG478.title: Services Marketing Management
MKTG478.description: Conceptual understanding of services and the analytical tools that are used in solving strategic services marketing problems.
MKTG478.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MKTG 301W C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS200W.title: Principles of Nursing Research and Evidence-Based Practice
NURS200W.description: Introduction to principles and methods of nursing research and application of, research evidence to practice.

NURS225.title: Pathophysiology
NURS225.description: Designed to explore the illness component of health with emphasis on the pathophysiological and psychosocial aspects.

NURS230.title: Introduction to the Fundamentals of Nursing
NURS230.description: Introduction to the nursing process, clinical competencies and psychosocial skills.

NURS245.title: Violence and the Impact on Society
NURS245.description: Interdisciplinary discussion of violence and its perpetrators, victims, and impact on society as well as possible solutions for violence reduction.
NURS245.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS250.title: Professional Role Dev I: Intro to Professional Issues in Nursing Practice and Nursing Informatics
NURS250.description: Introduces the students to the profession of nursing, the science of nursing, and the use of information technology in health care.

NURS301.title: Nursing Care of Client through the Adult Life Span Requiring Medical Intervention
NURS301.description: Therapeutic nursing care of the adult client in a variety of primarily medical-surgical settings.

NURS305.title: Introduction to Pharmacological Concepts
NURS305.description: Introduction to pharmacological concepts and identifies the pharmacodynamics of major classifications of drugs.
NURS305.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite NURS 225andNURS 230or approval of the program. Recommended Corequisites NURS 301andNURS 310

NURS306.title: Nursing Care of Children and Adolescents
NURS306.description: Focuses on common health problems and nursing intervention for children and adolescents.

NURS310.title: Therapeutic Nursing Care of the Older Adult Client
NURS310.description: Nursing concerns and intervention in promoting the health of the older adult.

NURS320.title: Nursing Care of the Childbearing Family and Gynecological Client
NURS320.description: Therapeutic nursing care of the childbearing family and gynecological client.

NURS325N.title: Health and Environmental Sustainability
NURS325N.description: This course covers the importance of environmental health on individual and community health, the effects of environmental hazards on diverse populations and the impact of climate change on disease.
NURS325N.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS352.title: Advanced Health Assessment for the Registered Nurse
NURS352.description: Designed to extend the RN student's knowledge and skills in health assessment and physical examination across the lifespan.

NURS357.title: Introduction to Nursing Informatics
NURS357.description: An introduction to nursing informatics focusing on technology applications to the nursing profession.

NURS390.title: Transition and the Professional Nursing Role
NURS390.description: Transition to baccalaureate education and professional nursing practice, emphasizing leadership, management, and issues influencing nursing education and practice.

NURS405B.title: Nursing Care of the Adult Client with Complex Health Problems: Part B
NURS405B.description: In-depth study of care of patients with acute and complex health problems, utilizing evidence-based practice.

NURS409.title: Introduction to Forensic Nursing
NURS409.description: Provides an introduction to the forensic health sciences, forensic nursing, and the nursing role in the scientific investigation of violence.
NURS409.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite NURS 225,NURS 230,NURS 250 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS410.title: Forensic Evidence Collection and Preservation
NURS410.description: Examines nurses' role of recognizing patterns of injury. Evidence collection procedures are examined from collection to courtroom presentation, includes autopsy.
NURS410.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 245andNURS 409 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS411.title: Seminar in Forensic Nursing
NURS411.description: A seminar to discuss the current topics, trends, and research related to forensic nursing, including evidence-based research, public policy issues, media-related events, regulatory considerations, professional responsibilities, and career planning.
NURS411.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 410 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS417.title: Family and Community Health Concepts
NURS417.description: Study of the concepts of family and community based nursing care emphasizing multicultural influences on health practices.

NURS420.title: Mental Health Nursing
NURS420.description: Emphasizes clinical application of mental health theory in nursing care of patients with acute and chronic mental health problems.

NURS430.title: Organization and Administration for the Nurse Manager
NURS430.description: Introduction to organizational theory and principles of practice in the administration of nursing services and patient care.
NURS430.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS431.title: Data Management for Nurse Managers
NURS431.description: Analysis of information systems to manage nursing service organizations. Includes financial management, the budgeting processes, and productivity measurement.
NURS431.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS432.title: Nursing Management of Human Resources
NURS432.description: Human resource management and related factors in nursing service organizations.
NURS432.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS433.title: Seminar for Nurse Managers
NURS433.description: Focuses on the application of management principles in the role of the nurse manager.
NURS433.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite NURS 430 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS440.title: Trauma/Critical Care Nursing
NURS440.description: Focuses on the impact of and the nursing care of persons experiencing acute trauma and/or critical illness.
NURS440.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS458.title: Ethical Challenges in Health Care Informatics
NURS458.description: A case-based collaboratory designed for the exploration and analysis of the ethical dilemmas facing health care informatics practitioners.
NURS458.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS460.title: Advanced Concepts in Clinical Nursing Informatics
NURS460.description: An exploration of clinical informatics tools to support informatics practice.
NURS460.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite NURS 357 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

NURS465.title: Health Concepts for Adults with Complex Health Care Needs
NURS465.description: In-depth study and application of the theoretical principles and roles of adult clients and families with complex healthcare needs.

NURS475.title: Integrated Concepts in Nursing Practice
NURS475.description: A project-based capstone clinical course for the RN student with a focus on the application of nursing concepts and the RN's development of future career goals. The course is designed to provide opportunity for students to synthesize and apply the art and science of nursing to health promotion and disease prevention in culturally diverse populations in varied clinical settings of the global community.

NURS495.title: Nursing Study in Specialized Setting
NURS495.description: Designed to provide students with in-depth study and practice in clinical specialty area of choice. Students work with a faculty member in the development of course objectives and goals and with a clinical preceptor to accomplish them.

NURS496.title: Independent Studies
NURS496.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

NUTR251.title: Introductory Principles of Nutrition
NUTR251.description: The nutrients: food sources and physiological functions as related to human growth and well-being throughout life; current nutrition issues.
NUTR251.prerequisites_raw: GHW This course can be used to satisfy the Health and Wellness (GHW) requirement.

OLEAD100.title: Introduction to Leadership
OLEAD100.description: This course introduces key leadership concepts and practices based on current theory and research. It is designed to help students to discover the knowledge and skills that are characteristic of effective leaders.
OLEAD100.prerequisites_raw: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

OLEAD201.title: Organizational Theory and Functions for Leaders
OLEAD201.description: Examines the nature of organizations along with its various interconnected functions such as leadership, financial, communications, technology, production, sales, etc.

OLEAD210.title: Evidence-Based Leadership
OLEAD210.description: Starts by examining different kinds of evidence and analyzing their quality and usefulness; students can then learn how to use that evidence to improve their leadership.

OLEAD220.title: Emotional, Social, and Cultural Intelligences and the Implications for Leadership
OLEAD220.description: This course focuses on emotional intelligence, social, cultural intelligence competencies used to develop the leadership capacity to be self-aware, understand oneself and others, and to work across cultural differences to effectively meet the demands of work.

OLEAD230.title: Leadership Across Industries
OLEAD230.description: Compares and contrasts leadership in different types of industries. In this course students will learn about the various types of organizations and examine why leadership in those organizations have some leadership characteristics that are similar and others that are different.

OLEAD409.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
OLEAD409.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

OLEAD410.title: Leadership in a Global Context
OLEAD410.description: This course explores the science and practice of leadership around the globe through pertinent scholarly literature and related instructional resources.

OLEAD411.title: Women and Leadership
OLEAD411.description: Through the review of literature and research on leadership, problem-solving in leadership scenarios, and self-assessment, students will gain a working definition of leadership and identify and develop leadership traits/competencies to encourage more women to be successful future leaders.

OLEAD464.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
OLEAD464.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

OLEAD465.title: Collective Decision-Making
OLEAD465.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

OLEAD496.title: Independent Study
OLEAD496.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

PHIL10.title: Critical Thinking
PHIL10.description: Discussion of the validity, soundness, and fallacies of everyday language use and reasoning; informal logic; and manipulative arguments and propaganda.

PHIL103.title: Ethics
PHIL103.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

PHIL103W.title: Ethics
PHIL103W.description: Focuses on ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability
PHIL103W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite LHR 100or 5th semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

PHIL105.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Law and Legal Ethics
PHIL105.description: Historical and contemporary philosophies of law; concepts of responsibility, property, rights, and justice; and ethical issues in legal practice.

PHIL119.title: Ethical Leadership
PHIL119.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

PHIL12.title: Symbolic Logic
PHIL12.description: In this course, students will first learn basic vocabulary for argument analysis, standards for evaluating arguments that are expressed in English, and basic methods for testing these arguments along with the shortcomings of said methods.

PHYS211.title: General Physics: Mechanics
PHYS211.description: Calculus-based study of the basic concepts of mechanics: motion, force, Newton's laws, energy, collisions, and rotation.
PHYS211.prerequisites_raw: Concurrent MATH 140 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

PHYS212.title: General Physics: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS212.description: Calculus-based study of the basic concepts of electricity and magnetism.

PLSC1.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
PLSC1.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

PLSC10.title: Scientific Study of Politics
PLSC10.description: This course introduces students to both the scientific study of politics and the way that study advances our understanding of political actors, events, processes, and institutions.

PLSC14.title: International Relations
PLSC14.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

PLSC17N.title: Introduction to Political Theory
PLSC17N.description: Introduction to basic issues in political theory through analysis of selected major political thinkers.

PLSC200N.title: Government and Politics of Europe
PLSC200N.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

PLSC210N.title: Rights in America
PLSC210N.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

PLSC3.title: Comparing Politics Around the Globe
PLSC3.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.
PLSC3.prerequisites_raw: PLSC 1 or PLSC 7 or CAS 101N or CAS 137H or ENGL 137H or CAS 215 or CAS 303

PLSC308.title: Introduction to Political Research
PLSC308.description: Introduction to conceptualization, research design, and measurement in political research.
PLSC308.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

PLSC309.title: Quantitative Political Analysis
PLSC309.description: Data analysis and statistical applications in political research, including data processing, inferential statistics, contingency analysis, correlation and regression, and multivariate analysis.
PLSC309.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

PLSC404.title: Analyzing of Public Policy in the American States
PLSC404.description: This course provides students with the tools to empirically evaluate policy proposals and outcomes in the American states.

PLSC410.title: Strategy and Politics
PLSC410.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

PLSC412.title: International Political Economy
PLSC412.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.

PLSC418W.title: International Relations Theory
PLSC418W.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.

PLSC429.title: Analysis of Electoral Politics
PLSC429.description: This course engages students in the empirical study of electoral politics in the United States.

PLSC438.title: National Security Policies
PLSC438.description: Impact of national security on U.S. government and foreign policy; roles and interaction of President, Congress, government agencies, interest groups.

PLSC439.title: The Politics of Terrorism
PLSC439.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.

PLSC442.title: American Foreign Policy
PLSC442.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.

PLSC447.title: Analysis of Public Opinion and Political Attitudes
PLSC447.description: This course engages students in the empirical study of public opinion.

PLSC456.title: Politics and Institutions of Latin-American Nations
PLSC456.description: Social forces and processes, governmental institutions, foreign policies of major states of Latin America.

PLSC467.title: International Relations of the Middle East
PLSC467.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.

PLSC468.title: Politics and the Media
PLSC468.description: An examination of how politics and public policy affect and are shaped by the news media, as a political institution, in America.

PLSC471.title: American Constitutional Law
PLSC471.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.

PLSC472.title: The American Legal Process
PLSC472.description: Analysis of the roles, procedures, and policies characterizing the American legal system.

PLSC473.title: American Judicial Behavior
PLSC473.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.

PLSC480W.title: Congress and the Presidency
PLSC480W.description: Basic characteristics and processes of the national legislature and executive; roles and interaction of these institutions in the policy process.

PLSC490.title: Policy Making and Evaluation
PLSC490.description: Advanced analysis of public policy, emphasizing policy evaluation and the factors that determine policy success and failure.
PLSC490.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite (PLSC 1 andPLSC 2)orPUBPL 304W C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

PLSC7N.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
PLSC7N.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

PPEM412.title: Turfgrass Disease Management
PPEM412.description: Introduction to biology of turfgrass pathogens and management of cool- and warm-season turfgrass.

PSYCH100.title: Introductory Psychology
PSYCH100.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
PSYCH100.prerequisites_raw: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

PSYCH105.title: Psychology as a Science and Profession
PSYCH105.description: Overview of history and methods of psychology as a science and profession; applications and ethical issues in psychology.

PSYCH200.title: Elementary Statistics in Psychology
PSYCH200.description: This course provides an introduction to the descriptive and inferential statistics commonly used in psychology, and to hypothesis testing as a method of scientific investigation. It also explores the ways in which the assumptions of statistical tests place constraints on experimental design and, conversely, how the design of experiments can dictate the statistical test appropriate for data analysis.

PSYCH212.title: Introduction to Developmental Psychology
PSYCH212.description: Developmental principles; physical growth; linguistic, intellectual, emotional, and social development from infancy to maturity.

PSYCH221.title: Introduction to Social Psychology
PSYCH221.description: Introduction to Social Psychology discusses how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by other people (real or imagined). The course will provide an overview of the field, potentially covering such topics as: attitudes, persuasion, person perception, automatic vs. conscious thought, the self, prosocial behavior, aggression, interpersonal attribution, conformity, obedience, culture, groups, prejudice and discrimination from a psychological perspective.

PSYCH231.title: Introduction to the Psychology of Gender
PSYCH231.description: The focus of this course in general is on the psychological study of gender in historical and contemporary perspective. The historical roots of gender studies in women's studies, as a correction to a traditional focus on male and masculine perspectives, will be covered.

PSYCH238.title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
PSYCH238.description: Personality psychology involves examining theories of human nature and evaluating them in an empirical fashion.

PSYCH243.title: Introduction to Well-Being and Positive Psychology
PSYCH243.description: Applying psychological knowledge to develop and maintain effective personal adjustment and well-being and positive social relations.

PSYCH256.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
PSYCH256.description: This course is an introduction to cognition, an area of psychology that investigates the ways in which we acquire, store, create and use knowledge.

PSYCH260.title: Neurological Bases of Human Behavior
PSYCH260.description: An introduction to biopsychology, emphasizing the structure and function of the human brain.

PSYCH270.title: Introduction to Abnormal Psychology
PSYCH270.description: This course focuses on some of the topics and questions people most commonly ask about psychology: What are the different psychological disorders, and what are they like? How do clinicians diagnose someone with a disorder? What do therapists actuallydoin therapy?

PSYCH281.title: Introduction to Industrial-Organizational Psychology
PSYCH281.description: Personnel selection, training, accident prevention, morale, and organizational behavior.
PSYCH281.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite PSYCH 100 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

PSYCH301W.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
PSYCH301W.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.

PSYCH404.title: Principles of Measurement
PSYCH404.description: An introductory course about properties of test scores such as reliability and validity. In addition, the course focuses on the construction and evaluation of measurement instruments used in educational and psychological settings and may include topics such as test development, score reporting, and interpretation. Basic statistics are introduced throughout the course to interpret the psychometric properties of scores.

PSYCH408.title: Program Evaluation
PSYCH408.description: Identify and understand the normative assumptions specific to organizations about their basic program design, implementation, and assessment processes.

PSYCH412.title: Adolescence
PSYCH412.description: Physical, cognitive, and personality development during adolescence.

PSYCH422.title: Human Sexuality
PSYCH422.description: Psychological influences on human sexual behavior such as love, sexual orientation, gender, intercourse, contraception, sexually transmitted diseases, dysfunctions, and paraphilias.

PSYCH424.title: Applied Social Psychology
PSYCH424.description: Application of social psychological theories and research methods to field settings and to the study of social issues.

PSYCH441.title: Health Psychology
PSYCH441.description: Overview of the field with an emphasis on how psychological research contributes to an understanding of health and behavior.
PSYCH441.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite PSYCH 100and 6 additional credits of PSYCH
