PSYCH470.title: Abnormal Psychology
PSYCH470.description: Causes, dynamics, symptoms, and treatment of neuroses, psychoses, personality disorders, and other psychological disorders of adulthood.

PSYCH482.title: Selection and Assessment in Organizations
PSYCH482.description: Background in personnel testing, performance measurement, selection strategies, with emphasis on validity and measurement reliability.

PSYCH484.title: Work Attitudes and Motivation
PSYCH484.description: Survey of theory and research with respect to attitudes, morale, and motivation of employees and management.
PSYCH484.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite PSYCH 100;PSYCH 200orSTAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

PSYCH485.title: Leadership in Work Settings
PSYCH485.description: Review of research and application of behavior principles in the areas of management and supervision.
PSYCH485.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite PSYCH 100;PSYCH 281or 3 credits MGMT; fifth-semester standing or permission of instructor C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

PSYCH490.title: Senior Seminar in Psychology
PSYCH490.description: Capstone experience for senior psychology majors; review of current research literature; topics vary.
PSYCH490.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite PSYCH 301Wand 6 credits in 400-level PSYCH courses

RHS100.title: Introduction to Disability Culture
RHS100.description: This course is designed to increase student awareness of personal, interpersonal, and societal aspects of disability, including how disability can be defined and understood differently in varied individual, institutional, and cultural contexts.

RLST1.title: Introduction to World Religions
RLST1.description: The course introduces students to the academic study of religion as well as to some of the major religious traditions of the world.

RPTM101.title: Introduction to Recreation Services
RPTM101.description: Introduction to discipline and exploration of professional career models/paths, historical development of profession, expectations and opportunities in recreation services.

RPTM115.title: Leadership Development in Snowsports
RPTM115.description: Leadership Development in Snowsports develops students' understanding and skills in becoming a Snowsports industry professional.

RPTM120.title: Leisure and Human Behavior
RPTM120.description: Leisure from historical and contemporary perspectives, including forces shaping leisure behavior, and relationships among leisure, the environment, and social institutions.

RPTM201.title: Introduction to Community Recreation
RPTM201.description: Introduces students to the role of community and nonprofit recreation agencies in generating benefits for individuals and communities. Topics include: the history of community and nonprofit recreation; environmental, economic, health, social, and human development benefits of recreation; access and equity issues in recreation and community sport; engaging communities in decision-making; the experience industry; and designing community recreation programs and spaces for meaningful experiences.

RPTM210.title: Introduction to Commercial Recreation and Tourism
RPTM210.description: Highlights the various roles that commercial recreation and tourism play locally, regionally, nationally, and globally. The course then shifts to focus on managerial considerations for practitioners in the field.

RPTM215.title: Snowsports Education
RPTM215.description: Snowsports Education is designed to guide students to become a certified snowsports educator. Students will need to join PSIA-AASI and pay for their level I assessment in addition to tuition fees.

RPTM220.title: Sustainability, Society, and Well-Being
RPTM220.description: Provides students with strong foundational knowledge about sustainability and how it relates to their career in recreation, park, and tourism management.

RPTM236.title: Leadership and Group Dynamics in Recreation Services
RPTM236.description: Supervision in recreation services, including theories, strategies, group dynamics, applied leadership, and decision-making skills.

RPTM277.title: Inclusive Leisure Services
RPTM277.description: Provides a review of leisure services and programs designed to be inclusive of individuals from underrepresented groups and an overview of professional, legal, and ethical issues.

RPTM300Y.title: Tourism and Leisure Behavior
RPTM300Y.description: Examines the impact of recreational sociocultural, governmental, economic, and physical environment on the leisure traveler within the tourism industry.

RPTM334.title: Nonprofit Recreation Agency Operations
RPTM334.description: Introduces students to the operational practices and missions of nonprofit recreation and tourism organizations. In particular, this course will allow students to investigate voluntary and semi-private sectors through membership strategies, fundraising and development roles, and volunteer management.

RPTM370.title: Introduction to Arena Management
RPTM370.description: Introduction to arena and facilities management, including operations, budgeting, marketing, and staffing.

RPTM390.title: Political and Legal Aspects of Recreation Services
RPTM390.description: Examines the governmental systems that influence the delivery of recreational services. The formal structure of government is considered along with the day-to-day political processes that determine public policy.

RPTM394.title: Orientation to Internship
RPTM394.description: Plan and prepare for an internship in recreation services. Analyze career opportunities, internship process, and associated requirements.

RPTM410.title: Marketing of Recreation Services
RPTM410.description: Theoretical/practical application of marketing/advertising strategies in the development/delivery of recreation services.

RPTM415.title: Commercial Recreation Management
RPTM415.description: Planning, developing, and managing profit-oriented recreation opportunities.

RPTM433.title: Program Evaluation and Research in Recreation Services
RPTM433.description: Systematic, structured problem-solving process for decision-making in recreation and parks. Research techniques/evaluation procedures; quantitative, qualitative methodologies; deductive, inductive reasoning.

RPTM435.title: Recreation Facilities Planning and Management
RPTM435.description: Planning and management of selected facilities with emphasis upon maintenance, activity, and support provisions.

RPTM456.title: Programming in Recreation Services
RPTM456.description: Provides information and practical experience required to successfully design, promote, implement, and evaluate programs and special events.

RPTM495A.title: Internship in Recreation Services
RPTM495A.description: Meet educational objectives through participation in an organized practical experience. In most instances, students are engaged in an off-campus learning experience that aligns with their specific field of study.
RPTM495A.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite RPTM 394andRPTM 456and seventh-semester standing and C average. Recommended preparation 300 hours practical experience and current and valid certification in advanced first aid and CPR or Wilderness First Aid/First Responder.

SCM200.title: Introduction to Statistics for Business
SCM200.description: Introduces basic statistical concepts and models within the framework of business problems and applications. Discusses the usefulness of business statistics to decision-making, how to perform basic statistical and analytical procedures, and how to interpret, critically evaluate, and analyze data.
SCM200.prerequisites_raw: MATH 21 or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination

SCM301.title: Supply Chain Management
SCM301.description: Supply chain management concepts, principles, and methodologies.
SCM301.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orECON 102orSCM 200orSTAT 200; limited to students in baccalaureate status.

SCM340.title: Introduction to Supply Chain Analytics
SCM340.description: Introduces strategic, tactical, and operational supply chain concepts including demand forecasting, risk analysis, revenue management, distribution, and facility location.

SCM445.title: Operations Planning and Control
SCM445.description: Aggregate production planning procedures, disaggregation methods in hierarchical production planning, sales and operations planning, master production scheduling, material requirements planning, production activity control, lot-sizing, and capacity planning.

SCM455.title: Logistics Systems Analysis and Design
SCM455.description: Customer service, inventory management, transportation, warehousing, purchasing, international logistics, site location planning and analysis, and total cost analysis.

SCM460.title: Purchasing and Materials Management
SCM460.description: Purchasing policies, procedures, order specifications and agreements, supplier selection, and the role of purchasing in production planning and inventory management.

SOC030.title: Sociology of the Family
SOC030.description: Family structure and interaction; functions of the family as an institution; cross-cultural comparisons.
SOC030.prerequisites_raw: Note not currently available through World Campus GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

SOC1.title: Introductory Sociology
SOC1.description: The nature and characteristics of human societies and social life.

SOC119N.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Culture
SOC119N.description: Focuses on historical patterns and current status of racial, ethnic and cultural groups and issues locally, nationally, and internationally.

SOC201.title: Presumed Innocent? Social Science of Wrongful Conviction
SOC201.description: The criminal justice system is a human creation and some errors are expected. Sometimes guilty parties go free and sometimes innocent people are convicted. In this course, we will employ the perspective of the social scientist to understand why and how wrongful convictions occur.

SOC207.title: Research Methods in Sociology
SOC207.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.

SOC404.title: Social Influence and Small Groups
SOC404.description: The study of social influence, leadership and status, and social cohesion and commitment processes in small groups.

SOC406.title: Sociology of Deviance
SOC406.description: Theory and research concerning behaviors and lifestyles viewed as significant departures from a group's normative expectations.

SOC409.title: Racial and Ethnic Inequality in America
SOC409.description: The impact of inequality and discrimination on individual and group identity among various racial and ethnic groups.

SOC455.title: Work and Occupations
SOC455.description: Work and occupational life in modern society; work in the past, present, and future.

SOC456.title: Gender, Occupations, and Professions
SOC456.description: The role of gender in shaping contemporary North American patterns of employment, occupational roles, and statuses.

SOC467.title: Law and Society
SOC467.description: Law and Society studies the social origins of law and legal systems, occupational careers, and decision-making of legal officials.

SOC5.title: Social Problems
SOC5.description: Current social problems such as economic, racial, and gender inequalities; social deviance and crime; population, environmental, energy, and health problems.
SOC5.prerequisites_raw: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

SOILS101.title: Introductory Soil Science
SOILS101.description: A study of soil properties and processes and relationships to land use, plant growth, environmental quality, and society.

SPLED461.title: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorders
SPLED461.description: This course will include an overview of characteristics and learning traits, classification systems, assessment strategies/issues, approaches, and interventions related to individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASDs). Special emphasis will be given to selecting evidence-based practices and enhancing collaboration among individuals with ASD, their families, and supporting professionals.

SRA111.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
SRA111.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

SRA211.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
SRA211.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
SRA211.prerequisites_raw: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SRA231.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
SRA231.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.
SRA231.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SRA 211andSTAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SRA268.title: Visual Analytics
SRA268.description: This course introduces the fundamental principles, methods, and tools of visual analytics that enable security and risk analysts to synthesize information and derive insight from massive, dynamic, ambiguous, and often conflicting data.

SRA311.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
SRA311.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
SRA311.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SRA 231 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SRA311W.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
SRA311W.description: This course provides students with the background, experience, and perspective required to document risk and identify policies and procedures that effectively deal with hazards and threats to which the organization is vulnerable, jeopardizing its mission.

SRA365.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
SRA365.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
SRA365.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite STAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SRA421.title: The Intelligence Environment
SRA421.description: The course examines the users and processes of Intelligence Community, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

SRA433.title: Deception and Counterdeception
SRA433.description: Deception tactics, technologies and procedures, and approaches to counterdeception analysis.

SRA440W.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
SRA440W.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.

SRA468.title: Spatial Analysis of Risks
SRA468.description: Helps students develop a spatial perspective on risk analysis and empowers them with GIS spatial data representation, visualization, and analysis methods that are fundamental to the spatial analysis of risk.

SRA471.title: Informatics, Risk, and the Post-Modern World
SRA471.description: Provides in-depth study of how security informatics is influenced by the risk and post-modern culture.

SRA480.title: Crisis Informatics
SRA480.description: This course examines how information and communication technologies have played a role in saving lives, specifically in the areas of technologies used toward emergency response.

STAT184.title: Introduction to R
STAT184.description: This course will introduce students to data computing fundamentals and a reproducible workflow using the R programming language and related tools. R is a powerful, open-source programming language used widely for applications in statistics and data science. Students will be expected to access, join, wrangle, clean, and visualize real data from various sources (e.g., CSV, HTML scraping, web URL, R packages).

STAT200.title: Elementary Statistics
STAT200.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
STAT200.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher. C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

STAT318.title: Elementary Probability
STAT318.description: Combinatorial analysis, axioms of probability, conditional probability and independence, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation, limit theorems, additional topics
STAT318.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite MATH 141 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

STAT460.title: Intermediate Applied Statistics
STAT460.description: Review of hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit tests, regression, correlation analysis, completely randomized designs, randomized complete block designs, latin squares.
STAT460.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite STAT 200orSTAT 240orSTAT 250orSTAT 401 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG311.title: Object-Oriented Software Design and Construction
SWENG311.description: Design, documentation, testing, and construction of software using software engineering strategies embodied in object-oriented programming languages.
SWENG311.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 122 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG411.title: Software Engineering
SWENG411.description: Software engineering principles including lifecycle, dependability, process modeling, project management, requires specification, design analysis, implementation, testing, and maintenance.
SWENG411.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 122 Concurrent SWENG 311 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG421.title: Software Architecture
SWENG421.description: The analysis and design of software systems using canonical design patterns.
SWENG421.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SWENG 411 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG431.title: Software Verification, Validation, and Testing
SWENG431.description: Introduction to methods of software verification, validation, and testing; mathematical foundations of testing, reliability models; statistical testing.
SWENG431.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SWENG 411 orSTAT 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG452W.title: Embedded Real Time Systems
SWENG452W.description: The design and implementation of real time systems.
SWENG452W.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite CMPSC 472orCMPSC 473orCMPEN 441 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG455.title: Engineering Quality and Security in Software
SWENG455.description: This course introduces software quality, the associated quality factors, software errors and the software quality assurance system.

SWENG480.title: Software Engineering Design
SWENG480.description: Concepts of engineering ethics, economy, and project management, senior capstone project selection, and technical communication skills.
SWENG480.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SWENG 431 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

SWENG481.title: Software Engineering Project
SWENG481.description: Capstone group design projects in software engineering.
SWENG481.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite SWENG 480 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

TURF230.title: Turfgrass Pesticides
TURF230.description: Covers chemical toxicity, formulations, environmental fate, labels, MSDS, calibration, IPM, safety, handling, storage, and Pennsylvania certification and regulations.

TURF235.title: The Turfgrass
TURF235.description: Characterization of the primary plant species used for sports, lawn and utility turf; includes turfgrass morphology, environmental adaptation, and cultural requirements.

TURF238.title: Turf and Ornamental Weed Control
TURF238.description: Introduction to the development of integrated weed management strategies utilizing a variety of cultural and chemical methods.

TURF307.title: Golf Course Irrigation and Drainage
TURF307.description: A study of irrigation topics with a strong concentration on turfgrass irrigation applications and a focus on surface and subsurface drainage.
TURF307.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite TURF 235 Recommend preparation MATH 21andSOILS 101 Note PLANT 217may not be substituted for TURF 307 for prescribed course credit.

TURF425.title: Turfgrass Cultural Systems
TURF425.description: A study of turfgrass maintenance practices and how their interrelationships can be utilized to develop management systems.

TURF434.title: Turfgrass Edaphology
TURF434.description: Characterization of soil's physical and chemical properties for the establishment and maintenance of sports turf; includes root zone construction.

TURF435.title: Turfgrass Nutrition
TURF435.description: Study of turfgrass nutrition and growth; emphasizing constructed and mineral soil fertility, nutrient uptake and function, and fertilizer-use efficiency.

TURF436W.title: Case Studies in Turfgrass Management
TURF436W.description: Case study and discussion considering integrated management of selected turfgrass sites; emphasis on problem analysis, principle application, and decision-making.

TURF490.title: Colloquium
TURF490.description: Oral presentations developed by students in consultation with the course instructor
TURF490.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite TURF 495 Note Seventh-semester standing Note Prerequisites may be waived by the course instructor if student demonstrates required level of competency.

TURF495.title: Internship
TURF495.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
TURF495.prerequisites_raw: Prerequisite Prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor

WMNST100.title: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
WMNST100.description: Review scholarly theories and research pertaining to womenâ€™s experiences and womenâ€™s status in contemporary American society.

WMNST105N.title: Living in a Diverse World
WMNST105N.description: Use literature, film, and scholarly texts to explore how conceptions of social difference, such as those linked to categories of gender, race, sexuality, class, ethnicity, and disability, shape society and everyday interactions historically and today.

WMNST106N.title: Representing Women and Gender in Literature, Art, and Popular Cultures
WMNST106N.description: Explore scholarly theories and research pertaining to women and gender while experiencing examples of contemporary womenâ€™s creative practice through the visual arts, media, and popular culture.

WMNST120.title: Sex, Gender, and the Body
WMNST120.description: This introductory course considers core topics in the field of feminist sexuality studies to both unsettle popular mainstream discourses on sexuality and to aid students in developing a more comprehensive, inclusive, and ethical lens through which to view intersections of gender, sexuality, and the body.

WMNST245.title: Introduction to LGBTQ Studies
WMNST245.description: Learn about the dominant themes in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies, with an emphasis on both literary and cultural studies. This course explores the history of modern, Western ideas about sexual identity as manifested in literature, theatre, film, and other narrative forms of popular culture.
